fields.biblequote: for God so love the world
fields.title: Harvest day
IMMODESTY AND INDECENT DRESSING Part Two
fields.word:
Dress can be controversial, and just the mention of modesty today can raise a lot of questions. But, there are and is clothes, timeless and pleasing to God, biblical, practical and motivating, it challenges women (young or old), to discover the truth about clothing and modesty.

Is the culture dictating the contents of our closet? Or are we dressing first and foremost to please God? Modesty is more than the length of your skirt or the cut of your blouse. But, its an issue of the heart.

Note that modesty starts in the heart. Its a heart issue before its a clothing issue. But, the principle of creation understanding, showed that men and women are different and wired differently by God!

• Men are affected more by what they see, by the visual.

• Women are stimulated more by touch and relationship.

Anybody who’s married knows that this is true. But its not just true sexually, its even true in other matters of morality, dress and so on.

The most common thoughts women have when it comes to matter of clothing is, “I can’t help it, if guys struggle morally because of what I wear. Its up to the guys to control their minds. I shouldn’t have to change the way I dress just because they can’t control themselves.”

Or, “Why should we have to make so many adjustments as women just because the guys can’t control their minds? Is this really my problem?”

Mrs. Richard Baxter said, "we as women need to walk in this world as if we were holding a candle walking into a room filled with straw or gunpowder."

Women need to be so careful that they don't by carelessness or our suggestiveness or anything about appearance or behavior that they don't light a match to fuel fleshly or sinful lust on the part of men. This is part of the responsibility of every women, except a women of easy virtues or prostitute or an unbeliever.

Reasons is that, we Christians are a family. The Scripture says in 1 Timothy 5:1-2 "Treat younger men like brothers, and older women like mothers, younger women like sisters, in [all] purity".

In the family of God, we are a family. It means we have to take care of each other, to think in terms of others and not just ourselves.Women are to be modestly under the principle of edification. To edify means “to build up, to encourage or to strengthen.”

In the Scripture we're told that we have a responsibility in the family of God to build one another up, to help each other, not just to live for ourselves for Hebrews 10: 24 says, "Let us consider [think about] how to stir up one another to love and good works."

When women go into churches or to the workplace or whatever, do you go thinking, “How can I encourage these men to be more godly?” I’m a candle walking into that room. I have a lot of power, a lot of influence, if I use that candle in the wrong way, I may cause a fire. I may cause an explosion.

The principle of edification says, "I'm willing to live according to the law of love." What’s the law of love? It says, I have a commitment to do what is best for others rather than wanting to live my life selfishly, just doing what pleases me. Romans 13:10 tells us that "Love does no wrong to a neighbor, therefore love is the fulfilling of the law".

If you truly and rightly loved God and men around you, the men in the Body of Christ, then you have fulfilled the law of God. The law of love says, "I don't want to defraud the men who are in my life, the men that God puts around me.

Now, what does it mean to defraud. Its an old-fashioned word that means “to deceive, to lead someone on or astray.” It means “to create an expectation that you cannot righteously fulfill; one who dresses in such a way that teases, seduces or tantalizes or tempts the men."

So, as a woman dresses or walks or conducts herself in such a way that invites men, she is saying, "I'm available; lm prepared to play the game as you can see, here's my body. Its an open invitation; come to my party," and if she then says, "I don't really want you at my party. I didn't mean it. Oh, I don’t want to do that! I don't want to get sexually involved; I just wanted to dress in such a way that I was sending you an invitation." Then he says, "I'm accepting your invitation. I'm coming to your party."

She says, "Oh, no, no, that's not what I had in mind." You know what she just did. She defrauded that man. She created an expectation that she could not righteously fulfill. Most Christian women I think don't realize when they're sending an invitation. They don't set out to defraud for the most part, but there dress and conduct do.

But, there are many women who do it intentionally and consciously, but I think very few Christian women are kind of clueless when it comes to some of these things. We're just fitting in; we're just doing what everyone else does. We're doing what comes naturally and don't realize that we are defrauding.

We are a part of a family, and we are responsible for those in our family who are weak. In many cases, that relates to men. That doesn't make men stupid or foolish. It doesn't mean that women aren't weak, but, they are just weak in different areas as men and women.

Romans 15:1 tells us, "We who are strong have an obligation to bear with the failings of the weak, and not to please ourselves." Ladies, “If you’re in the family of God, if you’re a child of God and submitting to Jesus, you have an obligation not to live for yourself.”

So in answer to the question, "Why should I have to change my clothing just because the guys around me can't handle it?" The answer is that we're family. We have an obligation to bear with the failings of the weak and not to please ourselves. As Romans 15:2-3 says "Let each of us please his neighbor for his good, to build him up." There's that word to edify him. "For even Christ did not please himself, but as it is written, 'The reproaches of those who reproached you fell on me".

Yes, some men in this world and some men even in our churches are wicked. They have wicked hearts, wicked intentions, and they will lust after women regardless of what you can do to prevent it. So in the case of those men, why would you want to help them sin? Why would you want to put further temptation in their path?

But, there's a whole other category of men and lots of these men in our churches, who are not wicked. They have a heart for God; they want to be godly men; they're not wicked. But as one writer says, "Your brethren in Christ may be weak." Just weak.

I think King David fit into this. The Scripture says "He was a man after God's own heart" in Acts 13:22. He was a man who wanted to please the Lord. He didn't get up that morning and say, "I think I'm going to lust after a woman. I think I'm going to commit adultery. I think I'm going to kill this man so I can have his wife." He didn't have wicked intent initially, but he was weak. He was particularly weak in the presence of an undressed woman, and most men are and would be.

Your Brethren in Christ may be weak, and the devil does all it can do, to weaken them further. They are forced to live in a world where they are continually bombarded with sights, which are designed by the enemy of their souls to weaken their morals and destroy their purity of heart, but must Christian women help the devil to do his work well, good and perfectly?

Must they make themselves a tool, a temptation to their brethren, even in the congregation of God? You women need to understand the fierce and bitter conflict in the souls of your brethren when you arouse their desires by the careless display of your feminine beautiful organs that ought to be covered.

If you love God, serving and following Jesus, and you wants to fulfill the principle and law of love! You would not plead for your right to dress as you please.

The fact is, you have no such right. You have no right to destroy by your careless dress, the brother for whom Christ died. “You were bought with a price and are not your own” says 1 Corinthians 6:20.

You are duty bound to glorify God in your body, to clothe that body not as you will but as God wills, and a little love for the souls of your brethren would remove forever from your heart the desire to dress as you please.

The question isWHY DON'T WE DEFER?Why don't we limit our liberty for the sake of our Christian brothers? Why aren't we more careful?Why are we so bent on dressing in ways that the world and Satan knows are designed to attract sexual attention? Why?Christ says if we are not building with Him, then we are scattering...

Keith Green says, “Unfortunately, it seems that many Christians are lost in their own selfish little world, either oblivious or uncaring about the effect and responsibilities they have on others. They may even appear to have a real excitement and love for the Lord; but, their dressing, body and conducts is sending out a totally different message”.

Keith Green a Christian woman says, “I know, because I have done it, partly in ignorance but mostly in rebellion. I can remember thinking, " Well, it's not my fault that they can't keep their eyes off me and on the Lord. They just aren't spiritual enough. Why should I have to change just because they are weak? The Lord showed me it was my fault”.

She continued “I was responsible for causing my brother to stumble, and it had to change. Once I really saw the damage my selfishness was doing to others and to the Lord, I was really ashamed of myself and embarrassed that I had been representing Jesus in such an unbecoming way”.

As Jesus said to us in Luke 17:1, "It's inevitable that stumbling blocks should come [there's going to be women in this world who dress sensually], but woe to those through whom they come!".

So the Scripture gives an example of a man in the Old Testament, Job, who said, “I have made a covenant with my eyes. How can I gaze at a virgin? I’m going to guard my eyes".

We think of that as being a verse for men, and it is, and it should be. They need to make a covenant with their eyes, to guard their eyes.

Could I suggest that women need to make a covenant, too? They need to make a covenant that by God’s grace they will never dress or conduct themselves in a way that would cause men to be sexually stimulated by the sight of what they see in them.

Paul tells us that he would gladly give up eating meat if it caused a brethren to stumble. Of course, we do not advocate giving up clothes, only ones that cause guys to stumble.

Ask yourself a few questions about your current clothing choices:

What do my clothing and external appearance communicate about who I am and what I believe?

Which aspects of the world’s philosophy have I adopted?

Do I need to make any changes in the way I think about my dress or appearance?Please tackle this question? You’ll have time to pray about them, record your thoughts, and reflect on actions you need to take. Continue from Part 3

fields.title: DRIED BONES CAN LIVE AGAIN!
fields.word:
Today we looking in the book of Ezekiel 37:1 “The hand of the LORD was upon me, and carried me out in the spirit of the LORD, and set me down in the midst of the valley which was full of bones”,

Bone, is one of the separate parts of the human or animal skeleton.

After death, bones retain their form long after the soft tissues have decomposed, so bones are often associated with dead bodies or with death itself.

In Ezekiel 37:2 “And caused me to pass by them round about: and, behold, there were very many in the open valley; and, lo, they were very dry”.

(white, bleached, brittle, even the worms wouldn't inhabit these bones now)

· A dry bone in this context refers to every area you may be experiencing a droughts or famine.

· Yes! Because a dried bone is lifeless; it can also refer to dead situations in one’s life.

· Here is the life that is without God.

· Here is the life that is wasted.

· Here is the life that has no hope.

· Drugs have left it desolate.

· Alcohol has broken it to pieces.

· The improper relationship has caused it to be without hope.

· Sin has destroyed it.

· Hopelessness is all around it.

· Despair surrounds it.

· Unhappiness overwhelms it.

· Dejected by its former self.

· Depressed by its current condition

· Discouraged by its failures

· Disheartened

· Disappointed

· Destitute

· It has no hope of ever returning to its previous glory.

· And so they’re abandoned.

· Even the man of God would not have known where they were

If God Himself would not have showed these bones to Him.

Ezekiel 37:3 “And he said unto me, Son of man, can these bones live? And I answered, O Lord GOD, thou knowest”.

"Can they live?"

Then Ezekiel remember who he is speaking to.

· Even the preacher had no hope for these slain.

· So He says “Only you know God”!

· If they were to live, he realized that it was going to take a real move of God.

NOTHING IS IMPOSSIBLE WITH GOD!

However, I have good news for you this weekend, every potential in you that has become dried-dead, shall rise again in Jesus name.

Ezekiel prophesied on dry bones as led and they began to locate each other even as flesh covered them up and they lived again.

We serve a God who isn’t new to the business of bringing dried (dead) bones to life.

i. When Sarah was 90 years old and God told her that she would bear a son, He reminded her…

Gen 18:14 “Is any thing too hard for the LORD?”…

God reminded Jeremiah…

Jer 32:27 “Behold, I am the LORD, the God of all flesh: is there any thing too hard for me?”

ii. The angel Gabriel reminded Mary… Luke 1:37 “For with God nothing shall be impossible”.

Jesus encouraged His disciples… Matt 19:26 “…With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible”.

iii. In John 11:20-45 Little wonder, Lazarus who was dead and buried for 4 days.

iv. Also, that child in 2 Kings 4:32-35 were both brought back to life.

v. Likewise, in 2 Kings 4:1-7, a widow had a last little pot of oil to feed and her children. But, Elisha told her to get as many drums as possible and fill them up from this oil. She poured and poured that all the drums were filled to the brim.

This woman sold them, paid all her debts and lived happily forever.

This weekend, as you decide to pray, God shall turn things around for you too in Jesus name.

Why? Because, her case was a financial dried bone, but God did it!

That’s why I’m being led to ask: What are your dry bones?

Is it your finances, jobs, marriage or open doors?

This weekend! They shall rise again!

Because, God is saying: “I will open your graves, and cause you to come up out of them” (Ezekiel 27:12 B).

Ø There is no such thing as a hopeless case.

Ø There are no hard cases

Ø There are no problems that are too big for our God.

Ø There is no situation that we face that comes as a surprise to Him.

New Life to the Lifeless

Ezekiel 37:4 “Again he said unto me, Prophesy upon these bones, and say unto them, O ye dry bones, hear the word of the LORD”.

(stop listing to other voices...listen to God)

We need to get into a place where we can hear his word.

·

· Some people can’t make it through the day with out a drink.

· Some can’t make it 1 hour without a smoke.

· What makes us think that we can go one day without the word of God?

· What makes us think we can overcome this world and it’s influences without His word?

Ezekiel 37:5 “Thus saith the Lord GOD unto these bones; Behold, I will cause breath to enter into you, and ye shall live”:

(only God can truly deliver from some things)

He said “I will cause”.

When you give your heart over to Him He goes to work on you.

· You couldn’t work hard enough to get that raise...

but all of a sudden God blesses you financially!

· God heals you!

· God delivers you from that addiction, demon, breaks the yoke of barrennesss, late marriage, ugly habit, enemy, etc.

· You couldn’t love enough to keep your marriage...but all of a sudden God is melting your hearts together.

· You couldn’t believe enough to be healed...then all of a sudden He Heals You!!!

· You couldn’t live good enough to save your self...So He dies on the tree and Saves You!

· God said He would do it.

· He would Save you

· He would heal you.

· He would deliver you.

· He would help you.

· ...it's when we forsake our own abilities and seek God's help!)

Ezekiel 37:6 “And I will lay sinews upon you, and will bring up flesh upon you, and cover you with skin, and put breath in you, and ye shall live; and ye shall know that I am the LORD”.

· This is the reason God has brought us to this place in life...That we might know Him!!!

· The reason He has allowed us to make such a mess of our lives is so that He could show us who He is!!!

Ezekiel 37:7 “So I prophesied as I was commanded: and as I prophesied, there was a noise, and behold a shaking, and the bones came together, bone to his bone”.

· {When God begins to put a life back together there is a noise.

· It might take some shaking up.

· It might take you finding yourself at the end of your rope.

· Or at the bottom of the pit.

· “When you’ve hit rock bottom the only

way to look is up!!!”

Ezekiel 37:8 “And when I beheld, lo, the sinews and the flesh came up upon them, and the skin covered them above: but there was no breath in them”.

They looked like soldiers...but they weren’t soldiers!

They looked like Christians...but in reality they were just dried up bones covered in flesh

· No life!

· No breath of God.

· No Holy Spirit.

· Ho Holy Ghost.

· No Power

· No anointing

Do you know something...Jesus said that

“you would receive power after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you!”

Ezekiel 37:9 “Then said he unto me, Prophesy unto the wind, prophesy, son of man, and say to the wind, Thus saith the Lord GOD; Come from the four winds, O breath, and breathe upon these slain, that they may live”.

When real revival comes into your life it will come from all directions.

Did you hear me? ... all directions!!!

· I’m talking about a God who can heal broken marriages.

· He can heal and diseased bodies.

· He can bless your finances.

· He can save your children.

· He can deliver you from addictions.

· He can bless you on your job.

· He can help you pay your bills.

· When His blessings flow… they flow from every direction.

· He said whatsoever you bind in earth shall be bound in heaven.

· He said ask and it shall be given

· He said ask and ye shall receive.

We just need for God to breath on us.

We just need for the Holy Ghost to move on us.

Acts 2:1 4 “And when the day of Pentecost was fully come, they were all with one accord in one place. And suddenly there came a sound from heaven as of a rushing mighty wind, and it filled all the house where they were sitting. And there appeared unto them cloven tongues like as of fire, and it sat upon each of them. And they were all filled with the Holy Ghost, and began to speak with other tongues, as the Spirit gave them utterance”.

The dead bones would live.

The sick shall be healed!

Demons shall be cast out!

The lam shall walk!

The deaf shall hear!

The dumb shall talk!

But they needed and need to "Hear the word of the Lord."

The Word of God is more powerful than we can ever imagine.

For Hebrews 4:12 says, “For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any two-edged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart”.

Ezekiel 37:10 “So I prophesied as he commanded me, and the breath came into them, and they lived, and stood up upon their feet, an exceeding great army”.

fields.title: THE LESSON OF PLAGUE
fields.word:
Our response to plagues begins with some of Jesus’s most famous teachings: “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you”; “Love your neighbor as yourself”; “Greater love has no man than this, that he should lay down his life for his friends.”

The Christian ethic in a time of plague considers that our own life must always be regarded as less important than that of our neighbor.

During plague periods in the Roman Empire, Christians made a name for themselves.

Antonine Plague of the 2nd century, which might have killed off a quarter of the Roman Empire, led to the spread of Christianity, as Christians cared for the sick and offered, spiritual model whereby plagues were not the work of angry and capricious deities but the product of a broken Creation in revolt against a loving God.

But the more famous epidemic is the Plague of Cyprian, named after a bishop it took its life. It helped set off the Crisis of the Third Century and triggered the explosive growth of Christianity.

Cyprian’s sermons told Christians not to grieve for plague victims (who live in heaven), but to redouble efforts to care for the living. Also, bishop Dionysius described how Christians, “Heedless of danger … took charge of the sick, attending to their every need.”

Even, a pagan Emperor Julian says of how “the Galileans” cared for even non-Christian sick people, while, the church historian Pontianus recounts how Christians ensured that “good was done to all men, not merely to the household of faith.”

This habit of sacrificial care has always reappeared throughout history. In 1527, Martin Luther stayed and ministered to the sick. Though his daughter Elizabeth died. But it produced a tract, “Whether Christians Should Flee the Plague,” Luther provides an answer: We die at our posts.

Christian doctors cannot abandon their hospitals, Christian governors cannot flee their districts, Christian pastors cannot abandon their congregations. The plague does not dissolve our duties, but, it turns them to crosses, on which we must be prepared to die.

For Christians, its better that we should die serving. And if we care for each other, if we share masks and hand soap and canned foods, if we “are our brother’s keeper,” we might actually reduce the death toll, too.

Caring for the sick sounds nice, but its as likely to infect others as to save lives. In an intensely professionalized medical environment, should common people really assume a burden of care?

Our bodies are gifts from God and must be protected, and we must not “tempt God.” Duetronmy 6:16 (“Though shalt not murder”) by even to endanger others through our negligence or recklessness. So, believers must obey quarantine orders, fumigate their houses, and take precautions to avoid spreading the sickness.

The Christian motive for hygiene and sanitation does not arise in self-preservation but in an ethic of service to our neighbor. We wish to care for the afflicted, first and foremost, but, not infecting the healthy.

Its interesting to know that early Christians created the first hospitals in Europe as hygienic places to provide care during times of plague, on the understanding that negligence that spread disease further was, in fact, murder. Exodus 20; 13 "You shall not murder".

The first sacrifice Christians must make to care for our neighbor is our convenience, as we enthusiastically participate in aggressive sanitation measures and social distancing.

This kind of humble care for others is a powerful force. The ubiquitous surgical masks may not actually prevent infection, but they serve as a visible reminder that we’re all watching each other’s backs.

When good sanitary procedure stops being about saving our own skin and starts being about loving our neighbor, it becomes not just life-saving but soul-enlivening.

This brings me to one of the more controversial elements of historic Christian plague ethics: We don’t cancel church. The whole motivation of personal sacrifice to care for others, and other-regarding measures to reduce infection, presupposes the existence of a community in which we’re all stakeholders.

Even as we take communion from separate plates and cups to minimize risk, forgo hand-shaking or hugging, and sit at a distance from each other, we still commune in the Lord.

Some observers will view this as a kind of fanaticism, but its not. The coronavirus leaves over 95 percent of its victims still breathing. But it leaves virtually every member of society afraid, anxious, isolated, alone, and wondering if anyone would even notice if they’re gone.

In an increasingly atomized society, the coronavirus could rapidly mutate into an epidemic of despair. Church attendance serves as a societal roll call. Those who don’t show up should be checked on during the week. Bereft of work, school, public gatherings, sports and hobbies, or even the outside world at all, humans do poorly. We need the moral and mental support of communities to be the decent people we all aspire to be.

The Christian choice to defend the weekly gathering at church is not, then, a superstitious fancy. Its a clear-eyed, rational choice to balance trade-offs and a Scriptural mandate. We forgo other activities and take great pains to be as clean as possible so that we can meaningfully gather to support each other.

Without this moral support, life can quickly become unendurable. Even non-Christians who eschew church-going can appreciate the importance of maintaining just one lifeline to a community of mutual care and support.

Be eager to sacrifice for others, even at the cost of your own life. Obsessively maintain a scrupulous hygienic routine to avoid infecting others. Maintain a lifeline to a meaningful human community that can care for your mind and soul.

These are the guiding stars that have shepherded Christians through countless plagues for millennia. As the world belatedly wakes up to the fact that the age of epidemics is not over, these ancient ideas still have modern relevance.

THE LESSONS OF CORONA-PLAGUE

1) It Changes Church worship!

Congregations are creatures of habit. Churches are built on traditions, liturgies, and order in worship. Over time, every church’s line between what is fundamental to the faith and what is merely institutionalized response gets blurred. But, CORONA Plague presents a needed moment of doctrinal stocktaking.

The biggest lesson for me has been navigating the road between wisdom and ignorance. Its tough as ignorance often has a way to masquerade itself as wisdom. How many precautionary measures are actually sound judgment?

Its a tough road to navigate, as we had to both convey safety to our members, by way of implementing recommended health measures and yet not succumb to the cultural climate of ignorance, fear, and self-preservation.

We do so in all our notices by ensuring that we are not just communicating measures but also casting a vision for how to be the people of God in this time.

In practical terms, a church’s response will vary depending on its doctrine, local context, and exposure to suspected cases of COVID-19. There is no correct answer; all are seeking the most appropriate response in extraordinary times.

Precautions that churches have taken to maintain services include:

To suspend their services entirely. We have to take the unprecedented step of suspending gathering, advising congregants to continue to fulfill their spiritual obligations by tuning in to online and Tv sermons, spending time in prayer, and reading the Word at home.

2) Be a Strong Leader and a Guidance! In moments of crisis, people are looking for leadership. The first responsibility of the leader is to remain calm. Be you a father or a mother. Panic causes tunnel vision, which is terrible for decision-making. Strong leadership reminds people that God is in control of every situation and there is never a reason to panic.

Praying, reading your Bible and researching process will drove you seeking divine wisdom in an unprecedented situation. It pours divine grace, provision and solution.

The biggest lesson that I have learned dealing with COVID-19 is the need to be humbler as a church leader. There is so much that I do not know and have to learn. And that increases my desire and the need to seek the face of the Lord daily.

As the virus continues to spread globally, church leaders around the world should be aware that their flocks are watching their shepherds intently. Signals of faithfulness will have implications long after the COVID-19 season is over.

A leader’s action is a theological statement! As leaders, we need to have a theological stance on all things. We need to process our fears before God and let our actions be inspired by faith and guided by sound theology. Let not disease, or earthly decree, but doctrine guide our decisions.

3) Taking Advantages of Technology! While the government has said an upgrade to the Red risk assessment level. The local churches have to explore and install or improve their audio and video recording and live-streaming instruments.

Its a wonderful time for the ecclesia to exercise practical wisdom and explore creative methods of ministry. Its Time to introduce Instant Message Broadcast and Live Video Streaming workshop and IT specialists to host a “Livestream Church Service”.

There is need for Bible Study Fellowship’s Life transmission to members. The move to livestreaming will strengthened the church community.

We have to be on a journey of rethinking our understanding of church. The church today must be a people of purpose that are willing to go beyond the constraints of ‘place’ or ‘program.

4) Its a eime Prayer! For such a time as this, unity is the key, a local prayer and church unity movement, is important. I believe in the power of prayer of agreement. For such a time as this, we need every believer to arise and seek God together.

A prophetic act, just like the ringing of church bells, summoning the faithful to action when their village or town is threatened.”

Its crucial that in times of crisis, the church rises up to be a standard. As salt and light, the church needs to stand strong in the Lord so that others can see the hope we profess.

5) Expect Criticism Outside and Inside! Inflammatory comments about race, religion and management must be stopped and erased! The criticism is unfortunate but unavoidable; non-Christians cannot be expected to understand the tenets and teachings of our faith.

But more painful is the criticism that has come from fellow Christians with every decision their leaders have to make. Decide to suspend services, and be castigated for a lack of faith. Decide to continue to gather, and be derided as socially irresponsible.

Be prepared to go deeper into prayer and Bible reading than you’ve ever gone. Be prepared for the reality that your decisions will not please everyone.

Crisis shows the true character of a Christian. The anxiety around COVID-19 will allow you to really discern the spiritual state of your flock.

If we respond to this crisis correctly, it can turn out to be a defining moment of discipleship for our community. In the face of imminent dangers, our priorities are rearranged. This is a great opportunity to have deep conversations about what we are living for.

Are we merely existing, or are we truly living? Are we living for the right stuff? Are we marching to the right drumbeat? Are we governed by biblical or worldly values? Are we living for what really matters?”

6) Love your neighbor! While much of the secular world’s response to the virus has been inward-looking, driven by fear, many Christian agree that the COVID-19 situation presents a God-given chance to shine in the darkness of the moment. However, for that to happen, the Christians must look beyond its own concerns and awaken to the opportunity.

One of the distinct things that we wanted to affect was the atmosphere of the community.

We can never fully remove these negative elements in society, “but what we can do is ensure that there are more positive vibes being generated than negative ones. So we sent our people out to care, to be kind and go the extra mile to help.

Among other efforts, Christians have to reached out to many who have been unable to earn a living because of lockdown, whose business and source of income has been badly affected. This is a must inside and outside.

Christians have to kick start many acts of love and kindness, as Viruses is spreading, alsi kindness, care and love is infectious too.

Anyone who stands in a relationship of service to another has a vocational commitment not to flee. Those in ministry, must remain steadfast before the peril of death.

The sick and dying need a good shepherd who will strengthen and comfort them and administer the communion.

Today’s condition challenges Christians to see opportunities to tend to the sick as tending to Christ himself (Matt. 25:41–46). Out of love for God emerges the practice of love for neighbor.

But I don’t encourage anyone to expose itself recklessly to danger. I mean one honoring the sanctity of one’s own life, and honoring the sanctity of those in need.

God gives humans a tendency toward self-protection and trusts that they will take care of their bodies (Eph. 5:29; 1 Cor. 12:21–26). All of us, have the responsibility of warding off this poison to the best of our ability because God has commanded us to care for the body.

I advise that public health measures such as quarantines and seeking medical attention when available is a must and not to do so is to act recklessly. Just as God has gifted humans with their bodies, so too he has gifted the medicines of the earth.

Though God’s children face earthly sufferings, those who proclaim faith in Christ share in a heavenly promise of freedom from illness and suffering.

Jesus Christ peace is not to remove us from disaster and death, but rather to have peace in the midst of disaster and death, because Christ has already overcome these things.

7) Amid bad news in the headlines, the Good News of Jesus Christ is more relevant than ever! The world has a virus infection that is far greater than all the viruses we’ve ever known throughout its history.

That virus is sin. And with this virus, there is absolutely no immunity, no survivors, and no hope. And it infects 100 percent of all humanity. No one is spared from this.

The world is in need of a Savior. The world is in need of salvation.

Headlines that regularly ratchet up the local and global death counts are daily reminders of our mortality, forcing everyone to look beyond the routines of life and to consider what lies beyond.

Note that we all will someday die, by COVID-19 or otherwise. Its a matter of urgency that a Christian is able to look beyond our present difficulties and look out for opportunities to share the hope that we have in Jesus.

We need conversations on deeper issues. Is the meaning of life and our time on this earth the prolonging and preservation of life for as long as possible? Is it to be occupied with temporal things, material wealth and comfort? Or is it to fulfill Jesus’ desire to see all the rooms in our Father’s house that he has prepared being filled to the brim?

This starts with a public, visible expression of the victory and hope that we have in Jesus. There is an unprecedented opportunity to share the reason for our posture of faith amid fearful times.

We do not live as those without hope that’s what the gospel is all about! But we have friends, neighbors, and family who do not know that hope.

They may open up to share their fears and concerns during such crisis. As the Old Testament prophet wrote in Daniel 12:3, ‘Those who are wise shall shine like the brightness of the sky above; and those who turn many to righteousness, like the stars forever and ever.”

The panic is tangible, also the love of the church can be tangible too. These are gospel moments. We can spread love, not fear and nor the virus.

Let’s not waste this opportunity.

In a climate of fear surrounding the outbreak, I come back to the scripture commitment to caring for the sick, whether they have coronavirus, tuberculosis, or influenza. Precautions, we shall take, yes. But we are reminded by the scripture that they are individuals deserving of care all the same.

“When did we see you sick?” ask the righteous in the parable of the sheep and the goats, to which Jesus responds, “Whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me” (Matt. 25:39–40).

If and when the coronavirus encroaches upon our communities, how will we faithfully respond?

fields.title: The Power  and Freedom  of Forgiveness
fields.word:
(Dear Sister Ngozi Agu, this is the little His grace enabled me to put down for now, forgiveness, as you requested. And it ANSWERED the QUESTION whether FORGIVENESS is for the STRONG or WEAK? Hoping it will be of help to you! Thank you, for giving me something to do)

We all make mistakes. In different spheres of life. They often lead to disagreement, strife, sorrow, anger or a sense of betrayal. Forgiveness is human too! We think of God as the final dispenser of forgiveness, but you and I, have the power to forgive as well. Doing so can help us avoid bitterness and resentment and often will salvage a relationship.

When to forgive and how to forgive, is a common question? When you feel mistreated, wronged or hurt by someone. These grudges contribute to the stories you tell yourself, on your own mental playlist.

These stories can become emotional yoke and passionate burdens, weighing you down in more ways than you realize. Blaming, whether yourself or others, puts you in the passenger seat, you playing the role of victim.

i. Forgiveness doesn’t mean what happened was OK. Forgiveness just means that you've made peace with the pain, and you are ready to let it go.

ii. Forgiveness is not something we do for others, but its something we do for ourselves. Not forgiving someone is the equivalent of staying trapped in a jail cell of anger and bitterness, serving time for someone else's crime. You make the choice to either dwell on the pain cause by others or you want to forgive and move on.

iii. Gandhi once said “The weak can never forgive. Forgiveness is the attribute of the strong." It takes a strong person to face pain head-on, forgive, and release it.

iv. Forgiveness isn’t always about others, its about forgiving yourself. Anger or guilt never makes anyone feel better.

v. To forgive someone is the highest, most beautiful form of appreciation, compassion and love that bring a sense of peace and happiness in return.

Note, always forgiving your enemies, annoys them so much, and paralysis and take away there power. By contrast, forgiving is empowering. You begin to operate from a position of strength rather than vulnerability.

Forgiveness is a gift. It breaks the cycle of negative energy that can hold you back from fulfilling careers, relationships and lives. It also reaps these benefits!

It Heals! Its impossible to move forward while ruminating over the past. When you forgive, you move the past where it belongs, in the past. Its not that you forget, its that you’re not stuck there anymore.

Forgiveness can be both cause and effect. Once you begin to heal, you can forgive. And once you forgive, you continue to heal.

Its Freedom! Resentment is a heavy burden and a yoke. There is an undeniable freedom in letting go of anger.

Its Self-Confidence! Whatever mistakes you made, whatever feelings of hurt, pain or sadness you felt, you survived.

It Resilience builds strength, compassion and confidence. When you forgive, you distance yourself from the influence of the person that hurt you. The challenge doesn’t define you; your resilience does.

Learning to forgive is a skill, and, like any other, the more you practice, the more natural it becomes.

Forgiving isn’t so much an act as it is a process. It begins with an understanding that you are not forgetting, nor are you condoning aggressive, offensive or abusive behavior. Rather, you choose to acknowledge and accept what happened, because it did, and to move on.

You may need time to process, but processing differs from ruminating. You may learn valuable lessons, about yourself, about others and about your values.

Forgiveness shift your mindset away from the role of victim. Regardless of the circumstances, you always remain in control over your thoughts and moods.

In the words of Viktor Frankl, “Between stimulus and response there is a space. In that space is our power to choose our response. In our response lies our growth and our freedom.” In that space, there is also opportunity for forgiveness.

Ministers of God are to truly invest their life ministry in seeking to see lost people reconciled to God, perfect saints in holliness and for the Church to build bridges instead of fences between its leaders.

We so often want ourselves to be forgiven before the Lord, but forget that real forgiveness is demonstrated by how we treat our brothers and sisters.

It is my opinion that real revival is not just getting the roof off and getting right with God. But, real revival is getting the walls down and getting right with one another.

We often need revival, with an emphasis of no roof and no walls. If we want the revival that nothing to separate US from God and nothing to separate US from the world.

When we forgive we set free ourselves and others at the same time. Forgiveness keeps us in right relationship with the Lord and in reconciliation with others.

There's a Costly Requirements for Forgiveness!Now, let me talk to you about the costly requirements for forgiveness, because, see, there's no bargain, forgiveness or no bargain pardons.

What does our Scripture say? "Be ye kind, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you" (Ephesians 4:32).

Now, Jesus is the model of our forgiveness since he paid the price. We talked about redemption through His blood. We will have to know a little personal Gethsemane and Calvary if you truly forgive somebody who has deeply hurt you.

We Need To Forgive Freely! The Lord's forgiveness is free, spontaneous, and quick. Don't forgive after you have collected your revenge. You know, sometimes people hurt us, and we say, "They don't know how much they hurt me, and I'm going to teach them how much I've been hurt. I'm going to make them suffer."

Has anybody ever treated you that way and then finally said, "Well, I'll forgive you?" What do you feel like saying? "Hey, I don't need to be forgiven. I've already paid."

You should be so anxious to forgive a person that you chase them and catch them in order to forgive them. Isn't that what God has done for us? We love Him why? Because, He first loved us.

When Adam and Eve sinned against God in the Garden of Eden, God did not sit up there, in Heaven, and say, "Well, I'm going to wait, and if, perhaps, they come to me, I might be persuaded to forgive them." God came to the garden, and God said, "Adam, Adam, where are you?" (Genesis 3:9).

That wasn't the voice of a detective. That was the voice of a brokenhearted God who was seeking someone who had sinned against Him, freely seeking to forgive.

We read, "Moreover, if thy brother shall trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault between thee and him alone"-it doesn't say to go and tell him off; go tell him secretly, privately, lovingly-and "if he shall hear thee, thou hast gained thy brother" (Matthew 15:18).

The act of forgiving someone is, in essence, your refusal to let anger and hatred prevent you from moving forward. You are taking a stand against allowing the actions of others to alter the course of your life or who you are.

Forgiving is not an act of weakness, but an act of great strength. Hanging on to upsetting experiences through our thoughts and words, is a clear message of weakness, immaturity and powerless. Its "drinking poison" and expecting the other person to die? Forgiveness is a perfect sense that only strong individuals are able to forgive?

1) Its a Vibration!

Every thought, word, action, and feeling has its own vibration. When you approach the concept of forgiveness from the perspective of the energy or vibration it produces and requires, it takes on an entirely new meaning. You will see that the qualities associated with forgiveness, love, peace, and happiness, are fast, high, empowering vibrational energies.

On the contrary, the qualities associated with unforgiveness, resentment, anger, hatred, are slow, low, disempowering energies. When you are unforgiving, you are throwing that negative vibrational energy out into the universe for yourself, not them, you!

Forgiveness is not about the other person. Forgiveness is about you taking the power back that you have relinquished to them. Its a display of courage and inner strength. It shows that you have so much integrity and love for yourself that you will not have your happiness stolen from you.

Exhibiting a peaceful nature shows that you are too strong to become offended by others' petty words and behaviors. You show that you are above the actions of another person because their actions are a reflection of their issues and have nothing to do with you and who you are.

2) Its a Matter of Freedom! After much of his life had been unfairly spent behind bars, Nelson Mandela had said, "As I walked out the door toward the gate that would lead to my freedom, I knew if I didn't leave my bitterness and hatred behind, I'd still be in prison." So, you must ask yourself, "Am I living in an invisible prison because I am unable to forgive?"

Unforgiveness is a prison of the heart, mind, emotion and passion. People who have hurt you are the cell walls, and your thoughts about them are the steel bars keeping you inside.

Without forgiveness, moving forward is impossible; the future is limited, and you become stagnant and if prolonged, it brings in retardation. Through unforgiveness, you turn the controls of your emotional and passionate life over to someone else, and there is no freedom in that. Forgiveness and letting go puts you in a place of power and freedom, it benefits you.

3) Its About Being Human! Everyone has been both the recipient and the giver of meanness, hostility, and insensitivity, etc., including you and me. It takes a certain degree of awareness, intelligent and elevation in consciousness to recognize that each soul who crosses your path is doing the best they can at their level of understanding and intelligent.

The person that has hurt you is a human being, too. We all make mistakes; no one is immune. And because of our humanness, internalizing the slow, debilitating energies of resentment and anger brings harm to us. It blocks our prosperity, our good, our happiness, and above all, our peace.

Forgiveness has nothing to do with the other person and does not condone their behavior in any way. They do not actually need to be involved in the act of forgiving them.

However, what I am suggesting is that the quiet contemplation of what your life would be like without their negative influence is important. And possibly the person that you need to forgive is you. Forgiveness is a gift that you give to yourself. The highest form of self-respect and Self-Love, is Self-Forgiveness.

Being able to forgive is admirable and shows great courage. Those who cannot forgive are letting their ego get in the way, it shows their poor sense of reasoning, and it shows how, weaken they are. Being strong enough to free one's Self from the prison of unforgiveness is a choice. Its a chance to be reborn, to fill your mind with peace, to heal, and move on, within that energy lies unlimited strength.

Peter asked the Lord: "Lord, how many times if a person sins against me, shall I forgive him? Seven times?"-that's a perfect number (Matthew 18:21).

Jesus said: "No, seventy times seven" -four hundred and ninety (Matthew 18:22). And, by inference, He didn't mean you stopped at four hundred ninety-one.

What our Lord says is, "Get the mathematics out of it. Don't keep score. Forgiveness has no limit. Forget the math." Forgive freely, even if you have to chase somebody in order to forgive them.

We Need To Forgive Fully! Now, if somebody comes to you and says, "I want you to forgive me." We should not say, "Don't worry about it."

This is a wrong response. We are to say, "I forgive you. I forgive you." This is very important. You see, sometimes, when we do wrong, we don't go to another individual and say, "Forgive me." We say, "If I have hurt your feelings, I'm sorry. I want to apologize."

The word apologize comes from a Greek word, apologia, which means, "to make a defense." In apologetics, we're defending the faith.

So many of us want to apologize. What we're doing is really defending ourselves. If you've wronged somebody, don't apologize and say, "Would you forgive me? I was wrong. I was wrong." It's not an apology that I want. I want forgiveness. And, if somebody has wronged you, don't say, "Oh, forget it. Never mind." Say, "I forgive you." Do it fully. Then it's buried in the grave of God's forgetfulness.

We Need To Forgive Finally! We should not bring it up again. Isaiah 43, verse 25: "I, even I, am he who blots out thy transgressions for mine own sake, and will not remember thy sins" (Isaiah 43:25).

Sins are buried in the grave of God's forgetfulness. If you forgive, do it finally, once for all. You may say, "Well, that brings up a problem for me.

God doesn't remember our sins anymore? I thought God was omniscient. How can God ever truly forget anything?" Well, intellectually, God cannot forget. God doesn't lose His memory. When God says, "I will remember them no more," that means, "I will not bring them up. I will not use them against you. If I remember them, I remember them as forgiven sins.

I don't continue to have that spirit of resentment that human beings tend to have. The sin is buried." Now, many times we say we have forgiven, but we've not forgiven finally.

We Need To Forgive! We also forgive forcefully. What do I mean by forcefully? It is not natural to forgive. Our spirits demand justice. "They need to pay. They hurt us and they need to understand just how badly they hurt us." It has well been said, "To err is human; to forgive is divine." You need Jesus to be forgiven, and, friend, you need Jesus in order to forgive. "Be ye kind, tenderhearted, forgiving one another" (Ephesians 4:32).

Where do we get that kindness? Where do we get that tenderheartedness? It comes from Jesus. The same One who has forgiven us is the One who puts His Spirit in us and enables us to have the force and the power to forgive.

The Certain Results of Forgiveness! I want you to think about the three-fold results of forgiveness. What will be the certain results of forgiveness?

Personal Emancipation!When there is forgiveness, there is personal emancipation. You're set free!

Mutual Reconciliation! There will be reconciliation. There's going to be a reconciliation between you and somebody else. You're going to gain your brother or sister. You're going to set free your brother or sister.

Spiritual Rejuvenation! There will be spiritual rejuvenation. There's going to be revival. Do you know what real revival is? Real revival is not just getting the roof off and getting right with God. Real revival is getting the walls down and getting right with one another.

I find it amazing that Christian leaders often preach forgiveness throughout the earth, but find it difficult to forgive one another or partner with one another.

The way we treat our brother and sister is a measurement of how much we truly the sacrifices of Jesus and shows how much we love our heavenly Father.

While we strive to win the world, let us be sure to keep our relationships with our brothers and sisters fresh and forgiven.

fields.title: THE NEED TO MOTHERS DAYS!
fields.word:
Mothers are the greatest and uncommon teacher of compassion, love and fearlessness. If love is sweet as a flower, then mothers is that sweet flower of love.

MOTHERS are walking miracle, as it hold their children's hands for a short while, but their hearts forever. Mothers are instinctive philosophers, for her heart is a deep abyss at the bottom of which you will always find forgiveness. Of all the rights of women, the greatest is to be a mother.

For MOTHERS are the bank where children deposited all there hurts and worries. All care, zeal and love begins and ends in motherhood, as mothers are readers, she reads the children.

Being a mother is difficult a challenging responsibility that is defiantly underappreciated. Been a mother and doing what mother’s do, takes patience and commitment. We should take time to honor our parents, all year long and not just on the "legal" day.

A six-year-old boy, separated from his mother in a supermarket, began to call frantically for “Esther! Esther! Esther!” That was his mother’s name and she came running to him quickly. “But, honey,” she admonished, “you shouldn’t call me ‘Esther’, I’m ‘Mother’ to you.” “Yes, I know,” he answered, “but this store is full of MOTHERS and I have only one MOTHER!”

On Mother’s Day we can’t say enough good things about our mothers, but we’ll try and God will help us!

1- Her hands work

2- Her mouth speaks

3- Her heart loves

Note that …

1~My first room, its My mother's womb

2~My first restaurant, its My mum's breast

3~My first toilet, its My mother's lap

4~My first school, its My mum's kitchen

5~My first Teacher, its My mum

6~My first doctor, Its My mum

7~My first thermometer, its My mum's finger

8~My first friend, Its my mum

9~My first dresser, Its my mum

10~My first vehicle, My mum's back

Thank you mum 4 all you did for me and long life to all mother's, in Jesus name.

A boy got his first job. As he was boasting about the amount of work he did, he said, "I get up at 5 a.m. and have my breakfast." He was asked, "Does anyone else get up too?" He replied, "Oh yes, mother gets up and fixes my breakfast and then fixes dad’s breakfast."

"And what about your dinner?" The boy said, "Oh, mother, fixes that too."

"Does your mother have the afternoon to herself?" The boy replied, "No, mama cleans the house, looks after the other children, and then gets supper for me and dad when we come home. Then we watch TV before we go to bed."

"What about your mother? What does she do?" The boy replied, "Mama washes some clothes and irons the rest of the evening."

"Do you get paid?" "Of course, Dad and I get paid."

"And what about your mother, does she get paid too?" The boy replied, No!

When Preacher John Wesley was a student at Oxford University, shocked by the amount of drinking done by the students. After writing to his mother, Susanna Wesley, for her counsel, he received the following words: "My dear son: remember that anything which increases the authority of the body over the mind is an evil thing."

A London editor submitted to Winston Churchill for his approval a list of all those who had been Churchill’s teachers. Churchill returned the list with this comment: “You have omitted to mention the greatest of my teachers, my Mother.”

Thomas Edison once said, “I did not have my mother long, but she cast over me an influence which has lasted all my life. The good effects of her early training I can never lose. If it had not been for her appreciation and her faith in me at a critical time in my experience, I should never likely have become an inventor. I was always a careless boy, and with a mother of different mental caliber, I should have turned out badly. But her firmness, her sweetness, her goodness, were potent powers to keep me in the right path. My mother was the making of me. The memory of her will always be a blessing to me.” What a loving tribute to a blessed mother, even Proverbs 31:28 says “Her children arise and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praises her”.

Preacher G. Campbell Morgan had four sons and they all became ministers of the gospel. At a family reunion, a friend asked one of the sons, "Which Morgan is the greatest preacher?" While that son looked at his father, he replied, "MOTHER."

Mother was the greatest teacher and preacher. Many mothers have done a lot of teachings and preachings to their children.

Thank your MOTHER for caring enough to tell you what was what.

Thomas Edison said above, Proverbs 22:6 “Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old, he will not depart from It”.

Every Godly MOTHER realizes that when Gods way is implemented early in a child’s life and within the home lifelong habits are established. God knew long before science figured it out that being a MOTHER and raising a family would be a very demanding and difficult thing to do.

Scripture in Proverbs 18:22 says, “Whoso finds a wife finds a good thing, and obtains favour of the LORD”.

If a child has a good MOTHER, that child is indeed blessed and favoured. Sadly, many of us do not realize how good our mother are until they are no more and we cannot show them the honor they deserve.

Its not easy raising a child at any time in life and as history can prove, but our MOTHERS did not care or matter the condition of life, time and season.

Many men often pick women with the qualities of their MOTHER. MOTHERS have eternal impact on their children.

Remember that Jesus loved His MOTHER very much, He did to teach us to love our MOTHER! When He said … “MOTHER see your SON and SON see your MOTHER”…

In the family of God, we have access to many MOTHERS. Jesus said that whoever does the will of God is His mother. Those women are my mothers also. The whole concept of the aged is that these women are experienced and wise.

But, not every woman with silver hair is wise or walking in holiness, and not every young woman is ignorant or spiritually immature. The whole issue is that the most experienced and most godly women are to teach the inexperienced and spiritually immature. There must be spiritual discernment.

Titus 2:3-5 “3The aged women likewise, that they be in behaviour as becometh holiness, not false accusers, not given to much wine, teachers of good things; 4That they may teach the young women to be sober, to love their husbands, to love their children, 5To be discreet, chaste, keepers at home, good, obedient to their own husbands, that the word of God be not blasphemed”.

Right things are not taught in our schools, the media, and often not by genetic mothers. How shall the young women know if spiritual mothers do not teach them?

The Good Lord created MOTHERS very special! With a smile, laugh and a kiss, MOTHERS can cure anything from a broken leg to a disappointed love affair.

God gave MOTHERS Six pairs of hands and three pairs of eyes. One pair that sees through closed doors when she asks, 'What are you kids doing in there?' when she already knows.

Another is in the back of her head that sees what she shouldn't but what she has to know, and of course the ones here in front that can look at a child when he goofs up and say. 'I understand and I love you' without so much as uttering a word."

Another is that that heals herself when she is sick, can feed a family of six on one pound of hamburger or little or nothing and can get a nine year old to stand under a shower."

The MOTHERS model is too soft but very tough! You can imagine what this mother can do or endure. Not only can it think, but it can reason and compromise. Then across the cheek of MOTHERS there's a leak, but not a leak, rather its a tear.

What's it for?"

It's for joy…

Its for sadness…

Its for disappointment…

Its for pain…

Its for endurance…

Its for forcus…

Its for loneliness…

And its for pride!

There is something so special about MOTHERSin Proverbs 31:10-31 “10 If you can find a truly good wife, she is worth more than precious gems! 11Her husband can trust her, and she will richly satisfy his needs. 12She will not hinder him but help him all her life. 13She finds wool and flax and busily spins it. 14She buys imported foods brought by ship from distant ports. 15She gets up before dawn to prepare breakfast for her household and plans the day’s work for her servant girls. 16She goes out to inspect a field and buys it; with her own hands she plants a vineyard. 17She is energetic, a hard worker, 18and watches for bargains. She works far into the night! 19-20She sews for the poor and generously helps those in need. 21She has no fear of winter for her household, for she has made warm clothes for all of them. 22She also upholsters with finest tapestry; her own clothing is beautifully made—a purple gown of pure linen. 23Her husband is well known, for he sits in the council chamber with the other civic leaders. 24She makes belted linen garments to sell to the merchants. 25She is a woman of strength and dignity and has no fear of old age. 26When she speaks, her words are wise, and kindness is the rule for everything she says. 27She watches carefully all that goes on throughout her household and is never lazy. 28Her children stand and bless her; so does her husband. He praises her with these words: 29“There are many fine women in the world, but you are the best of them all!” 30Charm can be deceptive and beauty doesn’t last, but a woman who fears and reverences God shall be greatly praised. 31Praise her for the many fine things she does.

These good deeds of hers shall bring her honor and recognition from people of importance”.

This verses is describing a woman who is living in a supernatural way with a supernatural God. And it has to be that way because there are few things that are more important to society than godly mothers. The Bible is clear in its teachings, both explicit and implicit, that the family is the foundation of society.

While fathers are responsible for the way the family goes, mothers are the glue that holds the family together. our wives/mothers are to be the keepers of the home while husbands/ fathers supposed to be the protectors of the home! The Scripture says “that home is keep by a wisdom of wife”…

This is a MOTHER living in what the Scripture says in Romans 12:2 which says, “Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind…”

Ephesians 5:25-29 “Husbands, love your wives, even as Christ also loved the church, and gave himself for it; That he might sanctify and cleanse it with the washing of water by the word, That he might present it to himself a glorious church, not having spot, or wrinkle, or any such thing; but that it should be holy and without blemish. So ought men to love their wives as their own bodies. He that loveth his wife loveth himself. For no man ever yet hated his own flesh; but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as the Lord the church: Husband is to love their wives, just like Jesus loves the Church. We are to love our wives sacrificially. If we fail to love our wives like this, we’re disobeying a commandment given to us from God’s Word, and we are distorting the picture that marriage provides of Christ and the Church to the world”.

You’ve heard the saying, “As goes the home, so goes the Church, and as goes the Church, so goes the world…” Well this passage is where that idea comes from. Christian marriage is a picture of Christ and His Church to the unbelieving world.

And secondly; if we fail to love our wives like this, we sin against God, against our wives and our children, because our kids pick up on our attitudes and actions.

Also, in Luke chapter 10 we read the story of Mary, Martha and Jesus. Mary found the time to sit at Jesus’ feet, to be near Him and learn from Him, while Martha kept herself busy with works, she even complained to the Lord about Mary’s unwillingness to join her in her sin. I hope everyone realizes that this is the same Mary that goes to the tomb and is the first person to see the resurrected Lord. She was then commissioned to be the very first evangelist. Jesus told her to go and tell the others.

And what we learn from that is that MOTHERS need to make Mary’s priority their own priority. It doesn’t mean that they ignore the other duties of motherhood. It means that they prioritize and have their priorities straight.

Because MOTHERS who end up making Martha’s priorities their own, end up like Martha. They find themselves full of resentment, self-pity and tension.

Jesus Himself took time to pray and be alone with His heavenly Father.

MOTHERS do you find yourselves so busy that you don’t take time to sit at the feet of the Lord and listen to His Word, and take your burdens and cares to Him?

The Bible makes it pretty clear that no WIFE or HUSBAND or MOTHER OR FATHER, can be the kind of spouse or parent that God has called them to be without the Lords help. Infact; Jesus said, “Without Me, you can do nothing!”

The woman who finds her value in her looks and beauty will either have so much painting and plastic surgery and Botox done that she’ll end up looking like something out of a horror show, or she will devalue her worth to the point of self-loathing, (Because age and gravity eventually sets in on us all). But the woman who fears the LORD, she shall be praised! “The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom”!

MOTHERS, God doesn’t call you to be perfect; He calls you to walk in His perfection. “Its not by might, nor by power, but by His Spirit – declares the LORD”. So take time to sit at the feet of Jesus, in-other-words, take time to get into the Word of God.

Read the Bible, study the Bible, learn the Bible, memorize the Bible… you do that, and before long, you’ll find that you’re living the Bible. Compare what God’s Word says with what the world says, and if they differ, reject the worlds point of view. And lastly; “keep your eyes firmly fixed on Jesus, lay aside every weight of sin that so easily besets us, and look unto the Author and Finisher of your faith”.

You must remember and never forget that God choose you to be a MOTHER.

Dear MOTHER, you are the greatest gift from heavens, filled with love and care for the family. Your smile and laugh brightens each day just as the morning rays shines on the hills and it’s without doubt it gives us the courage to face the new day with joy and purpose. How fortunate and special I am to be blessed with a mother as thoughtful, caring, loving and prayerful as you. You are that good gift, love and favour that is dear, rear and unimaginable that God gave. There’s no way I could ever fully express my gratitude for all you’ve done. You are so special, wonderful, awesome and phenomenal!

Happy MOTHER'S Day!!!

Its Love from

Pastor Eric C. Okechukwu

fields.title: THE TRUE FRIEND
fields.word:
(Dorothy T. Thomas, thank you for your encouragement and apreciation. I hope this shall be of help to you. This is the second part of the teaching about Friend & friendship you requested!)

Friendship is a simple word but carries deep meanings. It cannot be defined by a single phrase or a paragraph as it means different things to different people but to me in deep and naked truth, and Biblically, friendship means being there for each other, not only sharing in joys but sorrows as well, as thus said Galatians 6:2 "Carry each other’s burdens, and in this way, you will fulfill the law of Christ." Friendship is one of the most precious gifts of life, a true friend is the one who you can blindly trust and the one who you can rely on, anytime, anywhere and any season.

Who are your friends? Sometimes friends are closer than brothers or sisters. Friends are special and unique, they share affection, companionship, confidences, consideration, devotion, esteem, faithfulness, fellowship, harmony, helpfulness, loyalty, partnership, support, sympathy, trust and understanding. The Bible gives and speaks deep meaning of friendship in its naked and sincere reality in Deuteronomy 13:6 says “a friend who is as your own soul.” Mediate the image of that language in your mind: as your own soul. That is a biblical meaning and level of intimacy that is in friendship.

Friendship influences and impact hence Proverbs 13:20 says, “He who walk with wise men will be wise, but companion of fools will be destroyed”. Those that would be good must keep good company, as evidence, as a persons character is known by the company it chose, because wisdom lies in the choice of our company, for what they are, they will make us.

The Bible is full of examples of this. Think about the amazing friendship of Jonathan and David. Jonathan warned David that his life was in danger at the hands of Jonathan’s own father, King Saul. This warning allowed David to take action and avoid harm, and ultimately this act of true friendship allowed David to take the throne, manifest and fulfill destiny, which was God’s plan. True friendships are glued together with bonds of loyalty and commitment. They remain intact, despite changing circumstances.

Appleby, defined friendship as the great opportunity to demonstrate our capacity for lofty and ennobling relationships without the motive of selfishness. But, I define friendship as a bond that transcends all barriers.

Friendship is commitment of the heart, understanding, mutual loyalty and confidence and sharing. It settles for less than perfection and makes allowances for human weaknesses. Finding a true friend feels like a gift that keeps on giving, even when they are thousands of miles away for Proverbs 27:9 describes it thus, “A sweet friendship refreshes the soul”.

There’s something very real and refreshing about friendships that family relationships can sometimes lack. “You can choose your friends but not your family”.

God designed us to need other people to form, inspire, maintain and enjoy good relationships with others. People can be so much more effective, balanced and wiser as a result of developing and maintaining healthy friendships, for scripture says in Proverbs 27:17 A person sharpens the mind and life of it friend, make it more active and vigorous, because conversation promotes intelligence, infects and inspires. For wise and profitable discourse sharpens wits, impact knowledge, even looks, cheers the spirit and put briskness and liveliness into life.

The scripture says in Daniel 1:1-20 that Daniel and his three friends, Shadrach; Meshach; and Abednego who refused to be defied by the Babylonian king’s delicacies and their drinks are good example, because good persons graces, are sharpened by converse with the good, and the bad persons lust and passions, are sharpened by converse with those that are bad, as 2 Samuel 13:1-15 says, David had lovely beautiful daughter Tamar; and son called Amnon. 2 Samuel 13:11 . . . “As she was feeding him, he grabbed her and demanded, “Come to bed with me.” Amnon abominablly and incestuously rapped Tamar her blood sister from the same father, through the friendship, impact and advice of Jonadab, who was a very subtil and shrewd.

As iron is sharpened by its like, by the file, persons are filed, made smooth and bright, and fit for business, who were once rough, dull and inactive. The language of friendship is not words but meanings, action and impact. When the character of a person is not clear to you, look at his friends. Its obvious that friends influences, inspires and imparts and impact that Proverbs 22:24-25 says “Make no friendship with an angry man; and with a furious man thou shalt not go: Lest thou learn his ways, and get a snare to thy soul”.

Friendship is part of God’s way of life. His Word says much about friendship. A major underpinning in God’s plan is healthy, strong and close relationships. In so much as any one pushes you nearer to God, he or she is your friend. The Scriptures refer to Abraham and Moses as friends of God (Exodus 33:11; James 2:23). Jesus had close friends. Though the disciples were His closest friends, He had friendly relationships with others, including tax collectors.

The Talmud says, “A person without a friend or companion is like a left hand without the right”. It show examples and advantages of union in human affairs. But, 2 Corinthians 6:14 says, “Do not be unequally yoked together with unbelievers” . If none of your friends encourages you to obey God and live for God and continue walking in holiness, you have no friend at all. You are to have friends with those who bring you closer to God. We are not to yoke in friendship and acquaintance with friends who do not convert sinners and perfect saints in holiness.

I have been stabbed in the back by those I needed most. Also, I have been lied to, and against by those I love. I have been accused falsely that it made breaking news and headlines by those I blindly called friends. I have been framed up that I find it difficult even to deny while I am innocent by what I thought was a close and a dear friend. I have felt alone, but actually abandoned when I couldn’t afford to be, by who I regard as intimate friend.

But, by all this, I had to learn that a time and season has to come to test and vet the what, quality and genuineness and heart of everyone, anyone regards as or call a friend. Sharing our deepest secrets is a mark of great friendship. Even scripture says in Psalm 25:14 . . . “Friendship with the Lord is reserved for those who fear him. With them he shares the secrets of his covenant”. When God shares the secrets of his promises with us, we know that he considers us his friends.

The only way to have a friend is to be one. Life is partly what we make it and partly what it is made by the friends we choose. Life without a friend is death without a witness. We are all travelers in the wilderness of this world, and the best we can find in our travels is an honest friend. Friendship multiplies the good of life and divides the evil. Friendship doubles our joy and divides our grief. Friendship makes prosperity more shining and lessens adversity by dividing and sharing it.

Real friendship involves face-to-face honesty and loyalty. The strength and sweetness of friendship depend on sincerity tempered by sympathy. There is a vast difference between knowing someone well and being a true friend. The greatest evidence of genuine friendship is loyalty, "always loyal,” see 1 Corinthians 13:7, and being available to help in times of distress or personal struggles.

Hughes said, “Blessed are they, who have the gift of making friends, for it is one of God's best gifts. It involves many things, but above all, the power of going out of one's self, and appreciating whatever is noble and loving in another”. While Johnson said, “We cannot tell the precise moment when friendship is formed. As in filling a vessel drop by drop, there is at last a drop that makes it run over, so in a series of kindnesses there is at last one that makes the heart run over”.

Until friends loved, drawn close, struggles, suffered and linked together there is no sacred bond. There is a magnet in your heart that will attract true friends. That magnet is unselfishness, thinking of others first, when you learn to live for others, they will live for you. A true friend, freely advises justly, assists readily, adventures boldly, takes all patiently, defends courageously and continues a friend unchangeably. Friendship is always an act of recognition, with the creatures we don’t share a drop of blood with, yet hold the closest spot in our hearts. Friends are our family outside the closed walls of the house.

The batch, logo and key of friendship is what the scripture says in Colossians 3:13 says "Bear with each other and forgive one another if any of you has a grievance against someone. Forgive as the Lord forgave you." Because friendship with a person is friendship with its virtue and burden. For every true friend is a destiny partner, hence they find themselves enfolded in all of life affection. Constant friends make the hard times easier and the easy times better. All true friendship are and is, in a sense, covenantal. A true friend is someone who is there for you when he'd rather be anywhere else.

Friendship requires honesty, but we also know how to be honest without being open. Real friends don’t just know the truth about each other, they know the whole truth. They sometimes see us more clearly than we even see ourselves. The language of friendship is not words but meanings.

Friendship is one mind in two bodies. True friendship lasts till death and does not fluctuate from time to time. The essential qualities of good friends are trustworthiness, loyalty and honesty. But friendship is precious, not only in the shade, but in the sunshine of life, and thanks to a benevolent arrangement the greater part of life is sunshine.

Good friends enhance the quality, the pleasure, and the health of each other. we choose our friends, not our family, the personal and positive nature of friendship is voluntary.

Friendship may, and often does, grow into love and even into marriage, but love never subsides into friendship.

Most importantly, good friend value our presence in their life, though hard to find, harder to leave and impossible to forget. Research has shown that the better the quality of your relationships, the more likely you are to be happy. So, being a great friend to someone and having friends support your back is good for your wellbeing. A friend is, as it were, a second self.

A good friend walks the talk and shows their sincerity and care by their actions, big and small. They are the family we choose! There are friends, there is family, and then there are friends that become family. They give us company when we are lonely, support us unconditionally and accept us despite our shortcomings.

Friends help us grow at a spiritual level, as each soul is on a journey. Friends are guides who come into our lives, play their roles in our life. Don’t we all have friends who we were very close to us at one point, but with whom we are no longer in touch with now? They drifted away from our life when their role as guide was over.

As light shines through transparent objects, real friends can see into our souls. Over time, our friends learn our greatest joys and deepest sorrows. They learn our strongest beliefs, opinions, and fears. They know our most challenging temptations and our most shameful failures.

We crack open the doors of our souls to our friends. And when we don’t, our friends gently knock because they care enough to see how we’re really doing inside. Every one of us needs at least one person who knows us as well as we know ourselves, perhaps even better than we know ourselves.

True friends walk in the light together. The apostle John writes, “If we walk in the light, as he is in the light, we have fellowship with one another, and the blood of Jesus his Son cleanses us from all sin” (1 John 1:7). What does it mean to walk in the light? The light is the place of cleansing. Meaning darkness isn’t just the place where we disobey; its the place where we hide. But, the light isn’t just where we obey, but where we come out of hiding, where we open up about how we’ve disobeyed.

Walking in the light, then, isn’t about being perfect; it’s about admitting we’re not. As we confess our sins to God and others, we find real forgiveness and true fellowship (1:6–7). True friends speak with straightforward honesty and not in riddles. The English Puritan, Thomas Goodwin, wrote, “Simplicity and plain-heartedness is the truest and rarest jewel in friendship.”

With a friend we speak clearly, but also gently sometimes, and only when necessary, this means delivering hard words. We all need correction from time to time. The best people to give it are our closest friends. Proverbs 27:5–6 says, “Better is open rebuke than hidden love. Faithful are the wounds of a friend; profuse are the kisses of an enemy. A good friend loves enough to give these faithful wounds, and also loves enough to do it kindly”.

The anthem of friendship is that your friend rather be disappointed by the truth than be packaged, equipped and satisfied with a lie. Respect your friend, not because it respect you, but because your friend and friendship deserve respect.
