How pleased, would you be if you found out your friend respected you, only because it wanted you to respect it back or wanted something in return? Respect your friend because it deserve it. Listen to your friend because it deserve to be heard, not because it listens to you. Be nice to your friend because it deserve to be treated right. Care for your friend because its heart needs care. If your thoughts and feelings are not genuine, point them in a direction other than your friend. If I as your friend give you what you deserve, at least keep me away from what I don’t deserve.

Proverbs 17:17 says, A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity. Empathy is the ability to understand and adjust to someone’s emotional state. It is the capacity to enter his mind, to peer out at the world through its eyes. Empathetic friends weep with friends who weep and rejoice with friends who rejoice. We understand how they feel and why they feel it, as we also feel it with them.

Empathy shapes the whole tone of a relationship, without it, we trade honoring friends for one-upping them. We trade affirmation for sarcasm. We trade talking with for talking at. We trade listening to sorrows for changing the subject.

Over time we learn our friends’ temperaments, their moods, and their buttons. We know what makes them tick and what ticks them off. This all informs how we relate to them. We pick up on our friend’s emotional state and we adapt to it. As we do this, consideration serves as a primary way that we bear our friend’s burdens.

True friends keep confidences. We learn the importance of trust when it’s not there. One of the characters in the book of Proverbs is “the whisperer.” Proverbs 16:28 says, “A dishonest man spreads strife, and a whisperer separates close friends.”

Relationship don’t last because of good times, they last because the hard times were handled with the reality, care and service of friendship. The world and life is filled with honest, dedicated and available friends, if you can’t find, be one. Don’t just have and attend to a friend, but cherish, serve, give, invite, bear engage and participate in the friendship.

Proverbs 17:9 says, “Whoever covers an offense seeks love, but he who repeats a matter separates close friends.” The whisperer shares information, whether true or false, that should stay hidden. He wraps it up, labels it as a “concern” or a “prayer request,” and delivers it to whomever will hear.

Proverbs says, beware, because this severs even the closest relationships. Gossip erodes trust, and distrust erodes friendship. It is the opposite of safety. If you suspect that someone may talk about your issues behind your back, you won’t share them anymore. Suspicion will tint your lenses when you look at your friend. It will shade how you see every aspect of the relationship. When distrust enters you relationship, you may remain friendly, but you can’t remain real friends.

A South African proverbs says “A friend will be sure to act the part of an advocate before he will assume that of a judge”. “A true friend is the gift of God, and he only who made hearts can unite them”.

Friends need to reciprocate every marks. We may want someone to be our friend. We may show them affection, constancy, empathy, and so forth. But if this friend does not share the desire for friendship, it won’t happen. Friendship requires mutuality, mutual affection, mutual constancy, and so forth. Christians share common interests with friends as well, but they also unite around the most important thing about them. Friendships are always “about something,” and Christian friendship is, at its core, about Jesus Christ.

People without friends often experience the vulnerability of loneliness, that poignant state that many of us have felt at some point. Friendships are destroyed when boundaries are violated.

“A real friend is one who walks in when the rest of the world walks out, though hard to find, difficult to leave, and impossible to forget.” John O’Donohue said that “One of the tasks of true friendship is to listen compassionately and creatively to the hidden silences. Often secrets are not revealed in words, they lie concealed in the silence between the words or in the depth of what is unsayable between two people.” Titus Maccius Plautus said, “Where there are friends, there is wealth.” “Friends are the siblings God never gave us.” “A friend is a gift you give yourself.”

Philippians 2:3 "Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility value others above yourselves."

“Friendship consists in forgetting what one gives and remembering what one receives.” “No person is your friend who demands your silence, or denies your right to grow.” “Don’t make friends who are comfortable to be with. Make friends who will force you to lever yourself up.” Good friends are like stars. You don't always see them, but you know they're always there. An Irish Proverb Says “A good friend is like a four-leaf clover: hard to find and lucky to have”. It's not what we have in life, but who we have in our life that matters.

True friends are never apart, maybe in distance but never in heart. The only way to have a friend is to be one. One of the most beautiful qualities of true friendship is to understand and to be understood. There is nothing on this earth more to be prized than true friendship.

True friendship can afford true knowledge, as it depend not darkness and ignorance, but the best measures of its worth. A friend is an emotional bond and a human experience. Friendship is two-sided, for it isn't a friend just because someone is doing something nice for you. That's a nice person. Its called friendship when you do for each other, just like marriage, its two-sided.

There is one basic truth, there is some self-interest behind every friendship. There is no friendship without self-interests. Friendship marks a life even more deeply than love. Love risks degenerating into obsession, friendship is never anything but sharing.

This is a bitter truth Epicuru says, “Of all the things which wisdom provides to make us entirely happy, much the greatest is the possession of friendship”. Never do a wrong thing to make a friend or to keep one. “An insincere and evil friend is more to be feared than a wild beast; a wild beast may wound your body, but an evil friend will wound your mind, it’s the heart wound that kills.”

God’s way is not one of total independence from others. It is a way of interdependence of close relationships and of working together as a well-trained team to accomplish the goals He sets before us. All of us need to actively seek, develop and maintain friendships from a godly perspective and motive. We will be better people as a result.

Proverbs 18:24 “A man who has friends must himself be friendly, but there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother”. When scripture speaks about showing yourself friendly, it means putting forth effort and first becoming a friend to others!

An important aspect of being a true friend is showing openness honestly to others! A true friend is made by the quality of communication and service, not the amount. One bedrock rule from Proverbs 18:24 is that if you are not willing to attempt to be a friend you will not have friends. If a man do not maintain a friendly carriage, he cannot expect to retain his friends. Friendship is a good plant; but it requires cultivation to make it grow. "In doubtful times the genuine friend is known."

Luke 6:3 "Do to others as you would have them do to you." An example from History, when Solomon stated, “A man that has friends must show himself friendly: and there is a friend that sticks closer than a brother,” he knew exactly what he was talking about.

Now over 3,500 years later, the rules of friendship have not changed. The wise ruler understood that even though making and maintaining friendships is a daunting task, it produces companions who are as close, or closer than family. He knew that this wasn’t something that happened overnight, but took time and effort. If Solomon was willing to pay the price, how much more should we!

A friend is something which is indeed mutual and a stronger form of interpersonal bond than an association. A friend in need is a friend indeed, its a famous proverb to express the importance of friendships.

fields.title: IN FAILURE OR DEFEAT THERE IS A CAUSE!
fields.word:
Introduction

Its amazing that every story in the Bible has lessons for the people of God to learn of present truth.

We saw the abundant grace, thrill and bliss of miracles, like River Jordan stop flowing, the walls of Jericho fell, Psalm 114:4 says, “The mountains skipped like goats; the hills jumped about like lambs”, and the Kingdom of Jericho and it’s allied kingdoms were conquered.

God provides every avenue to make victory possible. At the same time, also He does not make defeat impossible. As a Christian, why should I say this, because God gave us the freedom of choice. We make choices that can lead to victory or failure.

After such a wonderful victorious experience at Jericho, chapter 7 is surprisingly to say the least. We saw failures opposite of God’s promises victories to Joshua and the Israelites.

Joshua 7:5 “The men of Ai 5chased the Israelites from the town gate as far as the quarries, and they killed about thirty-six who were retreating down the slope. The Israelites were paralyzed with fear at this turn of events, and their courage melted away”.

Here is the story of life and one we must learn to deal with, in our daily walk because this passage is so typical of most of us Christian today.

The distance between victory and defeat is only one step, and often only a short one at that.

The Canaanites steals, Robb’s, practiced the basest forms of immorality including child sacrifice. God had given them over four hundred years to repent, but now their iniquity had become full in Genesis 15:16 “It will be four generations before your descendants come back here, because I will not drive out the Amorites until they become so wicked that they must be punished.”

That is why the Lord God made it more clear in Leviticus 18:24-28 “Do not defile yourselves in any of these ways, for the people I am driving out before you have defiled themselves in all these ways. Because the entire land has become defiled, I am punishing the people who live there. I will cause the land to vomit them out. You must obey all my decrees and regulations. You must not commit any of these detestable sins. This applies both to native-born Israelites and to the foreigners living among you. “All these detestable activities are practiced by the people of the land where I am taking you, and this is how the land has become defiled. So do not defile the land and give it a reason to vomit you out, as it will vomit out the people who live there now".

The few who did turn to the Lord (Rahab and her family) were spared.

Joshua 7:1-12 "But Israel violated the instructions about the things set apart for the LORD. A man named Achan had stolen some of these dedicated things, so the LORD was very angry with the Israelites. Achan was the son of Carmi, a descendant of Zimri son of Zerah, of the tribe of Judah. 2Joshua sent some of his men from Jericho to spy out the town of Ai, east of Bethel, near Beth-aven. 3... they returned, told Joshua, “let only 3,000 warriors be sent, but they were soundly defeated. The men of Ai 5chased the Israelites and killed about thirty-six. The Israelites were paralyzed with fear at this turn of events, and their courage melted away. 6Joshua and the elders of Israel tore their clothing in dismay, threw dust on their heads, and bowed face down to the ground before the Ark of the LORD until evening and cried out, to God...” 10But the LORD said to Joshua, “Get up! Why are you lying on your face like this? 11Israel has sinned and broken my covenant! They have stolen some of the things that I commanded must be set apart for me. And ... lied about it and hidden the things among their own belongings. 12That is why the Israelites are running from their enemies in defeat. For now Israel itself has been set apart for destruction. I will not remain with you any longer unless you destroy the things among you that were set apart for destruction".

The Defeat of Israel by “Ai” is very important to us today Christian, this is because every defeat of God's people recorded in the Bible contains lessons for God's people today like in Romans 15:4 “Such things were written in the Scriptures long ago to teach us. And the Scriptures give us hope and encouragement as we wait patiently for God’s promises to be fulfilled”.

And 1 Corinthians 10:11. “These things happened to them as examples for us. They were written down to warn us who live at the end of the age".

Is there such a thing as defeat in the life of a Christian? Yes, but it does not have to happen! The Bible tells us that we are involved in spiritual warfare and that Satan is doing everything that he can to defeat us.

Ephesians 6:12 “For we are not fighting against flesh-and-blood enemies, but against evil rulers and authorities of the unseen world, against mighty powers in this dark world, and against evil spirits in the heavenly places”.

In fact, defeat should not be part of the normal Christian experience if we follow 1 Peter 5:8 “Stay alert! Watch out for your great enemy, the devil. He prowls around like a roaring lion, looking for someone to devour”.

The Disobedience of Israel is Defined in Joshua 7:1 “But the sons of Israel acted unfaithfully in regard to the things under the ban, for Achan, the son of Carmi, the son of Zabdi, the son of Zerah, from the tribe of Judah, took some of the things under the ban, therefore the anger of the LORD burned against the sons of Israel”.

The believer is in a greater danger of a fall after a victory, when we drop our guard and begin trusting in ourselves or in our past victories rather than the Lord.

One victory never guarantees the next. Only as it builds our confidence in the Lord and develops our wisdom in appropriating God’s Word do our victories aid us for the next battle.

In 1 Corinthians 10:12 it says, “The sons of Israel acted unfaithfully in regard …” Let’s note this problem facing the Israelites as a nation.

The word “unfaithfully” means “to act underhandedly or infidelity.” The sin as every sin was and is both an act of spiritual infidelity.

There was sin in the camp and God would not continue blessing the nation as long as this was so.

This does not mean this was the only sin and the rest of the nation was sinless, but this sin was of such a nature that God used it to teach Israel and us a couple of important lessons.

God viewed the nation of Israel as a unit. What one did was viewed as a sin for the whole nation because Israel’s corporate life illustrates truth and warnings for us as individuals (1 Cor. 10).

Achan’s behavior also illustrates how one or a few believers out of fellowship, when pursuing their own selfish desires and agendas, can negatively impact an entire group. Such behavior can create trouble for the rest.

“See to it that no one comes short of the grace of God and get defiled and immoral or godless like Esau, who sold his own birthright for a single meal” in Hebrews 12:15-16.

“Your boasting is not good. Do you not know that a little leaven leavens the whole lump of dough? Clean out the old leaven, that you may be a new lump, just as you are in fact unleavened. For Christ our Passover also has been sacrificed” (1 Corinthians 5:6-7).

1 Corinthians 5:6 Unjudged sin contaminated the whole assembly, ”Don’t you know that a little yeast works through the whole batch of dough?” (v. 6).

Hiding our sin can only hinders our progress in God’s will and plan Proverbs 28:13 “People who conceal their sins will not prosper, but if they confess and turn from them, they will receive mercy”, and creates trouble for others.

Numbers 32:23 reminds us, “be sure your sin will find you out.” This is similar to the idea of reaping what we sow because of the natural consequences of God’s spiritual and moral laws and because of God’s personal involvement.

The Numbers teaches us that sin will not only be discovered but that the consequences of our sin become active agents in discovering us and Galatians 6:7-8 “7Don’t be misled—you cannot mock the justice of God. You will always harvest what you plant. 8Those who live only to satisfy their own sinful nature will harvest decay and death from that sinful nature. But those who live to please the Spirit will harvest everlasting life from the Spirit”.

Sin is no small matter with God because sin is rebellion and rebellion is as the sin of divination in 1 Sam. 15:23.

Even though Christ died for our sins and stands at God’s right hand as our Advocate and Intercessor, God does not and cannot treat sin in our lives lightly.

Sin is against God’s holy character, and against His holy purposes for us. Sin hinders God control and ability to lead us.

The defeat of Israel’s army at Ai was embarrassing, because Ai was smaller than Jericho! How could such a defeat occur so quickly? The root cause, as summarized in verse one, was the sin of Achan.

This is one of the varying consequences of sin in the life of God’s people or in the life of the individual. Sin has many consequences, none of them good.

Joshua evidently failed to take time to get alone with the Lord to inquire of Him and seek His strength. If he had, he would not have remained ignorant of the sin of Achan and could have dealt with it first.

Four deadly errors were the result:

a. They remained ignorant of the sin of Achan.

b. They underestimated the strength of the enemy.

c. They over-estimated the strength of their own army.

d. They presumed on the Lord, they took Him for granted.

Let's look at the REASONS why Ai DEFEATED Israel!

1. The first reason is given to us in the first verse of chapter 7. Israel disobeyed the Lord. How? God had explicitly told His people (6:17-19) that when they conquered Jericho they were not to take any of the spoils of Jericho for themselves. But we read (7:1, 21) that a man named Achan stole some of the silver and gold which was to go into the treasury of the Lord and hid it under his tent.

Achan thought his little stealing means nothing and would not affect the treasury of the Lord or the welfare of the people.

But God saw it differently! Achan's sin of disobedience was the primary reason for the defeat of all Israel at Ai. God emphasizes this fact in His Word by stating it twice--both before (7:1) and after the defeat (7:11).

Think of it, not only did Achan's sin result in the defeat of Isreal by Ai, but God declared (7:12) that the whole nation could not move forward and that the whole nation would not have the Lord's help and presence unless the sin was judged.

Remember, this is all because of one man's secret sin. Check out verse 21 again and notice the snowballing effect. "...I saw ... I coveted ... I took ..." Little did Achan realize that his personal and private sin would affect all Israel.

What about our secret sins? Are you an Achan? Is the spiritual growth and progress of the group with whom you fellowship stifled because of your sin?

Is the presence of the Lord and help from the Lord limited, or hindered, within your marriage, family, or the church or Bible study you attend because of your personal and private sins?

These are heavy and maybe disturbing concepts, but they are Scriptural. God sees the fellowship as a whole. We cannot sin in a vacuum. We are not "islands unto ourselves". Like Achan, we don't begin to see the far-reaching effects and consequences of our selfish sins until it is too late.

Achan's sin was not that he robbed Jericho or even his own people; he robbed God. Do we rob God? We can rob God by wasting time, because it is His time. The same could be said in reference to the abilities that God has given us, as well as our material possessions.

All of our time, talent and treasure belongs to the treasury of the Lord. The idea that only a certain percentage is the Lord's and the rest is ours to use or abuse in any way we choose is foreign to the Scriptures.

We are robbing God when we fritter away our time watching "nothing" but TV. We are guilty of robbing the treasury of the Lord whenever we use our natural talents or acquired skills (as well as our money) to do things which are not pleasing to the Lord.

Sometimes the Lord's treasury is ripped off in the name of hobbies, or extracurricular activities, or "rest and relaxation"-when such good things are carried too far.

God would teach us from Joshua 7 that such robbery is not only sinful, but it leads to spiritual defeat in our own lives and detrimental effects on the spiritual growth of our brothers and sisters in the Lord.

Are we guilty of this sin? Are we defeated, and causing defeat in the lives of fellow believers, because we have robbed God of what rightfully belongs to Him?

2. Another reason for Israel's defeat at Ai was overconfidence. We see in verse 3 that Israel was so self-confident that they figured only two or three thousand men were needed to conquer Ai. How wrong they were! We see from Joshua 8:25 that their estimate of the enemy's strength was much too low.

Overconfidence will do this every time. Fear will make the enemy appear larger, but overconfidence will make the enemy appear smaller. Both extremes are wrong for the Christian warrior. We are not to cringe in fear before Satan and we are not to think we can fight him in our own strength. Our confidence must be in the Lord as the Bible says in Ephesians 6:10 "Be strong in the Lord, and in the strength of His might".

We growing Christians are particularly vulnerable to the problem of overconfidence right after a spiritual victory. That's the way it was at Ai. Israel had just won a major victory at Jericho. They were still on a "spiritual high".

Another reason of Israel's is that there’s was no communication with the Lord. We do not read of Joshua and the elders of Israel coming to the Lord in prayer until after the defeat (7:6-9). No wonder the Lord told Joshua to get up off his knees (7:10). There was no need to ask God why Israel was defeated (7:7).

God had clearly promised continuous victory to Israel if they would obey Him in Joshua 1:7-8 “7Be strong and very courageous. Be careful to obey all the instructions Moses gave you. Do not deviate from them, turning either to the right or to the left. Then you will be successful in everything you do. 8Study this Book of Instruction continually. Meditate on it day and night so you will be sure to obey everything written in it. Only then will you prosper and succeed in all you do”.

Continual communication with the Lord is essential for growing Christians. Many casualties of spiritual warfare would be eliminated if we would fall to our knees before the battle-not after we've experienced defeat.

Israel's sin had to be dealt with decisively. The fact that Achan's family was stoned and burned along with Achan (7:24) may seem like a rather harsh judgment, but it is probably a good indication that the family was also guilty. After all, it would have been pretty hard to bury the treasure inside the home tent (7:21) without the family being "in on it".

In any case, the lesson for us is pointed. We must deal ruthlessly with that which brings defeat in our lives-before it brings further defeat!

Is materialism bringing defeat in your Christian life? Then give away your material! Do you have a problem with unhealthy literature or art? Then don't buy or read or scan or browse or "peek at" unhealthy paperbacks or magazines.

This is what our Lord meant in Matthew 18:8-9 “8So if your hand or foot causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It’s better to enter eternal life with only one hand or one foot than to be thrown into eternal fire with both of your hands and feet. 9And if your eye causes you to sin, gouge it out and throw it away. It’s better to enter eternal life with only one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell”.

As Israel passed in review before the Lord (7:13-18), so we should examine ourselves in His presence and let His Word point out those "troublers" in our lives that are causing defeat. Also, Psalm 139:23-24says, “23Search me, O God, and know my heart; test me and know my anxious thoughts. 24Point out anything in me that offends you, and lead me along the path of everlasting life".

Hebrews 4:12 “For the word of God is alive and powerful. It is sharper than the sharpest two-edged sword, cutting between soul and spirit, between joint and marrow. It exposes our innermost thoughts and desires”.

fields.title: The World Won’t Come To An End!
fields.word:
Are you scared that the world is coming to an end? No …

The First Quarantine

The Adriatic port city of Ragusa (modern-day Dubrovnik) was the first to pass legislation requiring the mandatory quarantine of all incoming ships and trade caravans in order to screen for infection.

The order, which miraculously survived in the Dubrovnik archives, reads that on July 27, 1377, the city’s Major Council passed a law “which stipulates that those who come from plague-infested areas shall not enter [Ragusa] or its district unless they spend a month on the islet of Mrkan or in the town of Cavtat, for the purpose of disinfection.”

Mrkan was an uninhabited rocky island south of the city and Cavtat was situated at the end of the caravan road used by overland traders en route to Ragusa, writes Zlata Blazina Tomic in Expelling the Plague: The Health Office and the Implementation of Quarantine in Dubrovnik, 1377-1533.

By ordering the isolation of healthy sailors and traders for 30 days, Ragusan officials showed a remarkable understanding of incubation periods. New arrivals might not have exhibited symptoms of the plague, but they would be held long enough to determine if they were in fact disease-free.

In 430 B.C., Athens, the earliest recorded pandemic happened during the Peloponnesian War. The disease passed through Libya, Ethiopia, Egypt and entered Athenian, two-thirds of the population died. The disease weakened the Athenians significantly and was one factor in their defeat by the Spartans.

Also, in 165 A.D., Antonine Plague began with the Huns. They infected the Germans, who passed it to the Romans and then returning troops spread it throughout the Roman empire. This plague killed millions, and continued until about 180 A.D., claiming Emperor Marcus Aurelius as one of its victims.

Again, in 250 A.D., Cyprian Plague

named after the first known victim, the Christian bishop of Carthage. It starting in Ethiopia, it passed through Northern Africa, into Rome, then onto Egypt and northward. In 444 A.D., it hit Britain and obstructed defense efforts against the Picts and the Scots, causing the British to seek help from the Saxons, who would soon control the island.

Further, in 541 A.D., Justinian Plague first appearing in Egypt, the Justinian plague spread through Palestine and the Byzantine Empire, and then throughout the Mediterranean. It

killed about 50 million people, 26 percent of the world population. Its believed to be the first significant appearance of the bubonic plague, which features enlarged lymphatic gland and is carried by rats and spread by fleas.

Moreover, in 1350 The Black Death responsible for the death of one-third of the world population. It started in Asia, moved west in caravans, entering through Sicily in 1347 A.D. when plague sufferers arrived in the port of Messina, it spread throughout Europe rapidly.

England and France were so incapacitated by the plague that the countries called a truce to their war. The British feudal system collapsed when the plague changed economic circumstances and demographics. Ravaging populations in Greenland, Vikings lost the strength to wage battle against native populations, and their exploration of North America halted.

Furthermore, in 1492, The Columbian Exchange. Following the arrival of the Spanish in the Caribbean, passed along to the native populations by the Europeans. With no previous exposure, these diseases devastated indigenous people, with as many as 90 percent dying throughout the north and south continents. Upon arrival on the island of Hispaniola, Christopher Columbus encountered the Taino people, population 60,000. By 1548, the population stood at less than 500.

Further, in 1520, the Aztec Empire was destroyed by a smallpox infection. The disease killed many of its victims, incapacitated others and weakened the population so they were unable to resist Spanish colonizers and left farmers unable to produce needed crops.

Above apart, in 1665, The Great Plague of LondonFrom 1665 and 1666, the plague led to the deaths of 20 percent of London’s population.

More so, in 1817, First Cholera Pandemic infection originated in Russia, where one million people died. Spreading to British soldiers who brought it to India where millions more died. The reach of the British Empire and its navy spread it to Spain, Africa, Indonesia, China, Japan, Italy, Germany and America, where it killed 150,000 people.

Moreover, in 1855, The Third Plague Pandemic starting in China, moving to India and Hong Kong, the plague claimed 15 million victims.

Further, in 1875: Fiji Measles PandemicCame, after, a royal party visited Australia as a gift from Queen Victoria. The royal party brought the disease and it was spread further by the tribal heads and police who met with them upon their return.

The island was littered with corpses that were scavenged by wild animals, and entire villages died and were burned down, sometimes with the sick trapped inside the fires. One-third of Fiji’s population, a total of 40,000 people, died.

Again, in 1889 Russian Flu

started in Siberia and Kazakhstan, traveled to Moscow, into Finland, Poland, and moved into the rest of Europe. By the following year, it had crossed the ocean into North America and Africa. By the end of 1890, 360,000 had died.

In 1918, Spanish Flu that resulted in 50 million deaths worldwide. It was first observed in Europe, the United States and parts of Asia before swiftly spreading around the world.

It is said that during that plague, the living spent most of their time hurrying the dead in mass graves and yet others were left unburied.

In 1957, Asian flu starting in Hong Kong to China and then into the United States, the Asian flu became widespread in England where, over six months, 14,000 people died. A second wave followed in early 1958, causing an estimated total of about 1.1 million deaths globally, with 116,000 deaths in the United States alone.

In 1981, HIV/AIDS, First identified in 1981. First observed in American gay communities. AIDS has killed over 35 million people worldwide.

In 2003, SARS Was first identified, started from China, followed by 26 other countries, infecting 8,096 people, with 774 deaths. Quarantine efforts proved effective, the virus was contained and hasn’t reappeared since.

In 2019, COVID-19 Started from Wuhan, in China's central Hubei province. The first reported case in China appeared November 17, 2019, in the Hubei Province, but went unrecognized. Eight more cases appeared in December with researchers pointing to an unknown virus.

Many learned about COVID-19-19 when ophthalmologist Dr. Li Wenliang defied government orders and released safety information to other doctors. The following day, China informed WHO and charged Li with a crime. Li died from COVID-19 just over a month later.

Without a vaccine available, the virus spread beyond Chinese borders and by mid-March, it had spread globally to more than 163 countries. On February 11, the infection was officially christened COVID-19.

By today, corona death is not close to half a million, no. Whenever you feel frightened by corona, just know that it will never be recorded among world's top 21 pandemics, its not close.

The world is not ending with it, we shall live on. Well, people are dying but not even half will die. We shall remain.

* Stay Watchful

* Stay Faithful

* Stay Prayerful

* Stay Scriptural

* Stay Careful

* Stay hopeful

*Stay positive

*Stay home

*Stay Safe

SOURCES

Disease and History by Frederick C. Cartwright, published by Sutton Publishing, 2014.

Disease: The Story of Disease and Mankind's Continuing Struggle Against It by Mary Dobson, published by Quercus, 2007.

Encyclopedia of Pestilence, Pandemics, and Plagues by Ed, Joseph P. Byrne, published by Greenwood Press, 2008.

Influenza, The American Experience.

Source Book of Medical History, Logan Clendening, published by Dover Publications, 1960.

Timeline

1157 B.C. Pharoah Ramses V dies of smallpox

700 A.D. Smallpox endemic in India, spread to China, Japan, Europe, and north Africa

1518 Smallpox introduced to the Caribbean by the African slave trade

1520 Millions of Aztec people die in smallpox epidemic

1796 Jenner shows persons inoculated with cowpox virus are resistant to smallpox

1800's Vaccinia virus used in vaccinations against variola 1950

Most industrialized contries have eliminated endemic smallpox

1957 Tana pox epidemic in Kenya

1958 World Health Assembly accepts the global eradication concept Monkey pox virus discovered in laboratory primates in Copenhagen

1962 Tanapox epidemic in Kenya

1967 Smallpox Eradication Unit established at WHO

1970 Surveillance of monkey pox infections by WHO

1977 Global eradication of smallpox achieved

1979 World officially declared free of smallpox

1980's Molluscum contagiosum associated with immunocompromised patients

fields.title: THE HEALING VIRTUES OF HOLY COMMUNION
fields.word:
Jesus has made Himself the bread of life to give us life. Day and night He is there waiting for you!

Knowledge takes you far, but understanding takes you further; far beyond knowledge can. But, revelation brings to you the depth, breadth and length of God’s word, will and purpose. It opens your eyes to the deep things of God.

Therefore, it is necessary to have a clear understanding and deep revelation of the HOLY COMMUNION, and its healing VIRTUES and impact in our lives.

The Holy Communion is a meal, and you know, what goes into a man determines the life that is in him.

New King James Version John 6:48,50-51,53-56,58 "I am the bread of life. This is the bread which comes down from heaven, that one may eat of it and not die. I am the living bread which came down from heaven. If anyone eats of this bread, he will live forever; and the bread that I shall give is My flesh, which I shall give for the life of the world.” Then Jesus said to them, “Most assuredly, I say to you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink His blood, you have no life in you. Whoever eats My flesh and drinks My blood has eternal life, and I will raise him up at the last day. For My flesh is food indeed, and My blood is drink indeed. He who eats My flesh and drinks My blood abides in Me, and I in him. ... He who eats this bread will live forever.”

Your faith and belief is important, because faith makes spiritual sense to receive a miracle. God work in our life through faith.

The Holy Communion represents the greatest expression of God’s love for His people. It can change your life. Jesus instituted the communion in the church to be a usual continuous practice. Through this meal you can be reached by the healing power and be healed.

Two items are used in the Holy Communion, the bread which represents Jesus’ body that was scourged and broken before and during His crucifixion, and the cup which represents His shed blood.

God said, ‘I will bring you Health and Cure’, and has given us a powerful gift so that none of us would be sick, weak, or die young. The Scripture reveals how you can break free from the curse or spell of sickness through the Holy Communion!

In John 6:48-54 “Jesus says I am the bread of life; if you eat of this bread you will live forever".

"The Lords Supper is a personal fellowship with Christ. But, partaking of one bread creates fellowship between the members too; it merges them into one body, the church" The church is the many-membered body of Christ. It is not a building; it is made up of believers coming together.

The Bible calls us “living stones” in 1 Pet. 2:5 ‘you also, as living stones, are being built up a spiritual house, a holy priesthood, to offer up spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God through Jesus Christ”.

Stones that lie scattered on the ground are common, but once they are used to build a house, they become “living stones.”

We are also like “living water”, not stagnant water. We are meant to be constantly flowing and moving. The Bible describes the Spirit as “rivers of living water” in John 7:38 “He who believes in Me, as the Scripture has said, out of his heart will flow rivers of living water.”

Jesus said, “If anyone thirsts, let him come to Me and drink. He who believes in Me, as the Scripture has said, out of his heart will flow rivers of living water.”” John 7:37–38 NKJV

Every focus of CHRISTIANITY in preaching or teaching or other wise should be on Jesus Himself.

Our Lord Jesus Christ once said, “Verily, verily, I say unto you, Except ye eat the flesh of the Son of man, and drink his blood, ye have no life in you. Whoso eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, hath eternal life”…(John 6:53-56).

The greatest enemy of the believer is spiritual ignorance, not the devil, which has its cure in spiritual revelation. Every provision in the scriptures is only accessible by revelation.

In John 11:25, “Jesus said to her, "I am the resurrection and the life. He who believes in me will live, even though he dies”.

Holy Communion is one of the mysteries of the Kingdom. We operate by God’s Spirit who leads us in the mysterious grace of God. The Scripture says in Luke 8:9-10 9 “Then His disciples asked Him, saying, “What does this parable mean?” 10 And He said, “To you it has been given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God, ...”.’

The Holy Communion is a powerful gift that God has given us for there is supernatural power when you take it. Communion brings connection, as it focuses our hearts and minds of God and brings us into complete unity with Him.

When we take communion, we are recognizing the power of what Jesus did when He died on the cross. We are acknowledging His supernatural work and honoring who He is in our lives. We are saying, "I believe" with our actions.

More and more, Pastors is receiving testimonies from people who received their healing because of the Holy Communion.

Do you know that when one partook of the Communion, the presence of Jesus was "underneath" the bread and the cup.

Jesus is the Bread of Life. It is an anti-death, anti-barrenness, anti-miscarriages, anti-hard luck, anti-bewitchment, anti-unfavourable records, anti-evil ordinances, anti-ill/bad luck, etc.

When we partake of it, whatever is dying or dead in us is completely healed and restored. It is a ‘global Bread,’ with global impact; it works anywhere on earth (John 6:52 “How can this Man give us Hisflesh to eat?”)

When we partake of the Communion in faith,

we are empowered to live like Jesus sickness-free, sin-free and mentally sound like Him (John 6:57; Galatians 2:20).

The Communion is the Rod of God: Jesus is not only the Son of God; He is also the Rod of God (Isaiah 11:1 There shall come forth a Rod from the stem of Jesse, And a Branch shall grow out of his roots).

Jesus is the Rod that came out of the stem of Jesse with the seven Spirits of God upon Him (Revelation 4:5; 5:6).

In Exodus 7:10-14, Moses took the Rod of God and went to Egypt. When the Rod was cast down, it became a serpent and swallowed up the rods of the sorcerers and magicians of Egypt.

So, inside the Flesh is the Rod. When we take it in, it swallows the rods of the magicians (sickness and affliction).

Therefore, whenever you take the Communion, imagine yourself taking the Rod, that is, Jesus. As you take it, not one serpent of the magicians, wise men or sorcerers in your body will escape its power.

It is a Miracle Meal that neutralizes every poison in your Body: When eaten, every defiled part of our body is restored (2 Kings 4:40-41).

The Flesh of Jesus is the Miracle Meal that goes into our ‘biological pot’ (stomach) with its unlimited power and neutralizes every poison there.

Secondly, What is in the Blood? The Life of the Flesh: Every disease is traced to the blood,

because the life of the flesh is in the blood (Leviticus 17:11).

When we partake of the Blood of Jesus, there is a spiritual blood transfusion that ejects our defiled blood in exchange for His undefiled and incorruptible Blood. Therefore, whatever cannot be traced to His Blood disappears from our body.

The Conquering Power of God manifests when we partake of the Blood of Jesus, every evil spirit waging war against our health is crushed (Revelation 12:11).

So, the Blood of Jesus gives us victory and restores our health in a double fashion (Zechariah 9:11-12 "11 As for you also,

Because of the blood of your covenant,

I will set your prisoners free from the waterless pit. 12Return to the stronghold, You prisoners of hope. even today I declare that I will restore double to you").

The Communion is God’s method for dealing with every sickness of the spirit, soul and body. It is more than just a symbol of Jesus’ body and blood

But the book of Mark says “And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, blessed and broke it, and gave it to them and said, “Take, eat; this is My body.” Then He took the cup, and when He had given thanks He gave it to them, and they all drank from it. And He said to them, “This is My blood of the new covenant, which is shed for many.” ‭‭Mark‬ ‭14:22–24‬ ‭NKJV‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬‬

This account tells us that the disciples drank from the cup first, and then Jesus said, “This is My blood of the new covenant, which is shed for many.” This tells us that when you partake of the Communion, the bread and juice becomes holy and uncommon, in your body,

Jesus’ body broken for your health and Jesus’ blood shed for the remission of your sins.

You don’t need to have “great faith” to partake of the Communion.

The Holy Communion is the substance of the Pass Over in the Old Testament. In the Old Testament, their Communion was the Passover Lamb.

On the night of the Passover in Exodus 12, God told the children of Israel to take a lamb for every household. They were to eat the lamb roasted with fire (symbolizing Jesus on the cross).

While the Israelites ate the roasted lamb, judgment was happening outside their houses. The Angel of Death was going around killing the firstborn child of everyone who did not have the blood of the lamb on their doorposts.

God does not require great faith for you to eat. He only requires hunger and obedience to eat what He gives you. Even if some Israelites didn’t have faith, even if they were crying and afraid in their homes, as long as the blood of the lamb was on their doorpost, they were saved. Their security lay in the blood, not in their faith.

Similarly, even if the Egyptians were calm and had a “positive mindset,” they would have still died if they didn’t have the blood of the lamb on their doorpost. It’s not about positive thinking, it’s about the blood. Without the shedding of blood, there is no forgiveness of sins.

Jesus died for you. His blood has been shed for the remission of your sins. Partake in the Holy Communion by being conscious of the truth that its Gods grace and previous for divine healing, empowerment and restoration.

Holy Communion is so important that God personally revealed it to Paul and he said

“For I received from the Lord that which I also delivered to you: that the Lord Jesus on the same night in which He was betrayed took bread; and when He had given thanks, He broke it and said, “Take, eat; this is My body which is broken for you; do this in remembrance of Me.” In the same manner He also took the cup after supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in My blood...

To read more go to www.siftersnews.com

Without a revelation of the Communion, “many are weak and sick among you, and many sleep.” The Lord watches over this revelation.

It is important to Him.

God wants you healthy. God wants you strong.

God wants you to live a full life. The Communion is more powerful than you realize.

When a Gentile woman came to Jesus for healing for her demon-possessed daughter, Jesus told her that healing is the “children’s bread.” The woman replied, “... even the little dogs eat the crumbs which fall from their masters’ table.” And Jesus healed her daughter (see Matt. 15:22–28).

So, if the crumbs can drive a demon out,

you, child of God, don’t just have a crumb.

You have the whole piece of bread. The mysterious extraordinary power of the bread and the cup is much and divine.

God is not asking for more than what is in your hand. You can simply use crackers, bread, and grape win, ordinary juice, wine or whatever you have that can symbolize the body and blood of Jesus.

It's not the elements that hold the power; it's your faith in Jesus and your surrender to Jesus. It's your obedience to His Word that says, "Do this in remembrance of Me."

Honour the Lord through communion. Open your heart to Him and discover the blessing of fellowshipping with our heavenly Father in such a personal way.

The Holy Communion might be small, but it is mighty. It is so powerful that the devil is terrified of it. It is God’s provision for us so that we don’t have to suffer the sickness and death that the world is suffering.

God is saying, “I have given you a provision—the body and blood of my Son. If you would partake of it, you will escape the condemnation and sentence on the world.” There’s a sentence on this world because of sin: sickness and death. Christians are not to suffer that sentence because Jesus’ blood was shed for the remission of our sins.

To read more go to www.siftersnews.com

The number one thing Jesus did besides preaching is healing all who were sick. He NEVER gave anyone sickness. He was always providing. Always supplying.

Sickness and death began with a simple act of eating. Healing in our lives will begin with a simple act of eating HOLY COMMUNION.

Don’t just hear about the Communion. But, actively partake of it.

To read more go www.siftersnews.com

Sometimes, the healing does not happen instantly. It happens incrementally. But it will surely happen.

Every exploit in life is a product of knowledge.

Know that you are healed because of the stripes that Jesus took on His back. Every stripe that He was given He saw you and those things that are afflicting you today.

To read more go www.siftersnews.com

fields.title: ALLOW GOD TO INSPIRE YOU THIS  LENT FASTING PRAYER
fields.word:
Inspiration is the process of being mentally stimulated to do especially something creatively.” It is a “divine influence or action on a person believed to qualify and amplify him or her to receive and communicate sacred revelation.”

It takes God to see God. God is the source of inspiration, therefore, we need Him to rule us and our world. It takes inspired mind to enjoy inspired revelations. In the kingdom, life is either of grace or disgrace, and inspiration is a bye product of God’s grace. The Scripture says in Job 32:8 “But there is a spirit in man but the inspiration of the Almighty giveth them understanding”.

Inspiration is a phenomenal mystery that only God can explain. The Holy Spirit is the source of Inspiration. It takes a life in God to hear God and live in God. Inspiration is God telling you what the scriptures say so that you can understand them, and who and what you are in life.

In the kingdom, destiny is built and manifested on the platform of inspiration. If you are not inspired you will not be magnified to manifest, but expire. Expired product does not have value in the store shelve. When you lack inspiration you will not be amplified to attract relevance. If you are not inspired to live your life in the principles of God, you may expire quickly on earth.

Through this LENT season, things happen in the kingdom by inspiration, not by human wisdom. Yes, we have God’s sense, not traditional, none world or worldly sense. We live in God’s sense, mercies and grace. It takes knowledge of God’s sense, mercies and grace to live in good and bad times of life.

It takes God’s sense and grace to read beyond the lines of traditional and worldly values. Worldliness makes you rate yourself above value and above others, but God inspires your real worth, rate and value. Inspiration is born out of God’s persistent consciousness in the soul of man. Only God’s presence can revive the mind and make it active and creative.

The Scriptures says in Psalm 119:105 “Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path”. It takes the light of God’s word in the mind to walk with God on earth. Your mind must first be inspired before your life can aspire for the next level. God is inspired by the righteous act of the righteous to inspire it.

You can only have a better life by inspirational revelation of God. The secret of your life is based on what you do with the divine instructions you received from God.

The Scripture says in Psalm 119:11 “Thy word have I hid in mine heart, that I might not sin against thee.” A soul is a faculty of reasoning and reasoning is a function of information. Whatever you give your soul to receive, store and believe, will influence the destination of your thought and life.

This is why our academic excellence does not qualify us as citizens of heaven. Mathematical formulas, economic postulates, accounting and legal principles cannot qualify us for heavenly revelation and inspiration. They can only influence our reasoning after we have met Christ.

Abraham heard God and was inspired, and in obedience made generational history. Gideon was inspired and began to do unusual things on earth during a difficult time. God saw it, noticed him and commissioned him. Solomon embarrassed God with unequal sacrificial seed sowing and God inspired and crowned him with phenomenal wisdom, knowledge and insight and wealth beyond the reasons, thought, imagination and comprehension of earthly being till this day.

The Scripture says in John 6:2-3 KJV “And a great multitude followed Him, because they saw His miracles which He did on them that were diseased. And Jesus went up into a mountain, and there He sat with His disciples”. The ministry of Jesus is anchored on inspiration. I call it God’s sense in a mortal man. It means reasoning beyond the natural phenomenon. Often going to the mountain for divine inspiration, to make impart and impart life.

Inspiration could mean reasoning beyond the natural phenomenon. Inspiration is an act of the mind, touched and empowered by divine grace. It is the mind of God sown into your spirit that enhances and magnify the value of your performance and confidence.

Dearly beloved, it takes inspiration to remain relevant and make impart on your world. Holy words make Holy men. Inspiration is enhanced by holy living. Get involved in Lent fasting and prayers, it is an opportunity to be inspired and be transfotmed. It takes God in the mind of man to be inspired by the Spirit of God.

This season is the eve of Easter. The position attracts good values and divine visitation. This season of “LENT” fasting and prayer is designed to inspire you and cause great transformation in life situation. The Holy Spirit is the inspirator. He is the within and the anointing upon spoken of by Jesus in John 14:17 “Even the Spirit of truth; whom the world cannot receive, because it sees him not, neither knows him: but you know him; for he dwelles with you, and shall be in you”.

It convicts the mind and reveals God’s authority and values. It enforces and inspires divine order in the conscience of men. Allow what you believe to inspire your mind to attract what you desire and deserve. Work on your heart and make it stabilized so that God can get involved in your dreams.

Every dream that ignores God is a comedy, like an African comedy. The company you keep will influence what you believe, what you do, where you go, what you see and hear and what inspires you.

Inspiration develops by hearing inspired words and by practicing them. Success and failure are by-products of the mind. To live for God is a decision to succeed and be inspired. What you are withdrawing from will determine what you are drawing to. Inspiration is a by-product of covenant decision.

Prophetic words are covenant tools that turn situations around. In this LENT season, open up your heart and the power and grace of God will inspire your destiny forward. The

Scripture says in Proverbs 11:24-2 “There is that scattereth, and yet increaseth: and there is that that with holdeth more than is meet, but it tendeth to poverty. The liberal soul shall be made fat: and he that watereth shall be watered also himself”.

Kingdom life must be live by inspiration, even the Scripture is the basis for inspiration. Resourceful labour that must yield harvest must be inspired.

Believe God, you will find life more interesting.

Thanks and God bless.

Yours in His service!

Pastor Eric C. Okechukwu

fields.title: A NEW YEAR  AND NEW BEGINNING
fields.word:
New is the YEAR, new are the hopes and aspirations, new is the RESOLUTION, new are the SPIRITS.

The newness of the year inspires to a great height, for all great things have begun anew.

New Year means new dreams, new beginning, new chances and new feelings. May this be a New Year of new hope, new opportunities, new adventures, and new ways to give and love.

Happy New Year! This is the first Sunday of this New Year! The holidays are over, the family and friends have gone home, the Christmas presents have been opened, and now its time to go back to work and school!

One major concern is the New Year resolutions we make and then so quickly break. We told ourselves, next year I’m going to be more active in church. Next year I’m going to get my finances in order. Next year I’m going to get into better shape.

God offers us more hope than that. In 2 Cor. 5:17, it says, “Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has gone, the new has come!”

Also Phil. 4:13 advice us, “I can do everything through him who gives me strength.”

As we approach this New Year, I want us to be praying a prayer of thanksgiving, “Thank you, Lord, for fresh starts.”

A new calendar tells us that we have been given a fresh gift to build and change our lives. Every New Year and every New Day is an opportunity to get it “righter” than the day before and the year before.

So on this first Sunday of the New Year, I want to encourage us to make a commitment to focus more on spiritual things in this New Year.

The Scripture in Col. 3:1-3 says, “Since, then, you have been raised with Christ, set your hearts on things above, where Christ is seated at the right hand of God. Set your minds on things above, not on earthly things. For you died, and your life is now hidden with Christ in God.”

Those of us who are Christians have experienced both a spiritual death, and a spiritual birth. All of our hopes and dreams, purpose and power are centered in Christ, who is seated at the right hand of God.

Our focus and priorities must no longer be centered in the things of this earth, but on the things of God.

This, of course, is a very real challenge, because we still have to live in the real world, with all of its stress and struggle.

Focusing on spiritual things does not remove the stress and struggle altogether, but it certainly makes a huge difference in our ability to both survive and thrive.

As we try to live a more spiritually focused life in the New Year, I want to point us toward 7 practical priorities.

First Priority- Forget About Yesterday. In Phil. 3:13-14 it says, “But one thing I do Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus.”

As we know, Paul was a man who had some things from his past that could haunt him if he let them. He had made some terrible mistakes that brought great suffering to others.

There is not one of us who doesn’t have something negative in our past that could immobilize us.

Failures, hurts, disappointments, etc., happen to all of us. But God does not want us dwelling on them.

God would have us come to him for forgiveness and healing about the pain and regret of yesterday.

It is God’s gift to us that we can walk in newness of life, that we can forget those things in the past and live in the present. So that’s a good place for us to start the New Year, to forget about yesterday.

Second Priority - Don’t Worry about Tomorrow. I know that this is easier said than done. Tomorrow can be so overwhelming with the potential for pain, lack and insufficiency.

Jesus gave us prescription in Mt. 6:25-27, 32-34 “Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or drink; or about your body, what you will wear. Is not life more important than food, and the body more important than clothes? Look at the birds of the air; they do not sow or reap or store away in barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not much more valuable than they? Who of you by worrying can add a single hour to his life?...So do not worry, saying, ‘What shall we eat?’ or ‘What shall we drink?’ or ‘What shall we wear?’ For the pagans run after all these things, and your heavenly Father knows that you need them. But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well. Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own.”

Jesus’ promise is that God knows what we need, and that God will provide what we need. Our job, however difficult it might be, is to trust and obey God.

Seek first His kingdom. In other words, stay faithful in obedience and pray. The Scripture says in Phil. 4:6-7, “Do not be anxious about anything, but in everything, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and minds in Christ Jesus.”

I’m not trying to pretend that any of this is easy, but I am certain that there is no better way.

Corrie Ten Boom, who had suffered greatly in her life said, “Worry does not empty tomorrow of sorrows; but it empties today of strength.”

Our only hope and help is in trusting in the Lord. Whatever we face in this New Year, we will be better off if we make it a priority to forget the past, and not worry about the future.

Third Priority - Make Today Count.

The famous funny man, Groucho Marx, said, “Yesterday is gone - tomorrow isn’t here yet. I have just one day – today, and I can choose how I shall be! And I choose to be happy!!”

The only day we have and the only moment we have is now. We are not promised tomorrow, nor even the rest of today!

For Psalm 118:24 says, “This is the day the LORD has made; let us rejoice and be glad in it.”

As we try to take life one day at a time, and make each day count, we can do so by walking with the Lord.

We can thank God and rejoice in each day and ask God to guide us and help us make each day count.

Focusing on one day at a time frees us from the burden of the past, and the worry of the future.

Fourth Priority - Help Every Person You Can.When we focus all our attention on ourselves, we get lost in our struggles, but when we turn our attention outward, we realize the tremendous blessing of helping others.

Every person we encounter is facing some kind of challenge, or is carrying some kind of heartache.

Our own personal struggles or heartaches maybe bigger or smaller than theirs, it makes no difference.

If we seek to be a blessing to everyone we meet, then both of us will be blessed.

Its written in Galatians 6:10, “Therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people, especially to those who belong to the family of believers.”

In the chapter before that one, Paul beautifully summarized the Christian life with these words, “The only thing that counts is faith expressing itself through love.” (Gal. 5:6)

Living for Christ is all about loving and giving. Love makes everything lovely, especially you and me.

What a great year and great life we can live if we focus on others and attempt to help every person we can!

Fifth Priority - Keep Your Heart Pure.

In the Sermon on the Mount, Jesus says in Matthew. 5:8, “Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God.”

Any mechanic will tell you that a clean engine runs better and delivers more power than a dirty one.

The same is true of a pure heart. We make a terrible mistake when we collect and retain all kinds of garbage in our hearts.

I’m thinking of things like evil desires, resentments, malice, bitterness, jealousy, hatred and thoughts of revenge.

These things eat away at us like a cancer.They poison our hearts and block our ability to see God and experience a vibrant spiritual life.

The Scripture says in Col. 3:5-10, “Put to death, therefore, whatever belongs to your earthly nature: sexual immorality, impurity, lust, evil desires and greed, which is idolatry. Because of these, the wrath of God is coming. You used to walk in these ways, in the life you once lived. But now you must rid yourselves of all such things as these: anger, rage, malice, slander, and filthy language from your lips. Do not lie to each other, since you have taken off your old self with its practices and have put on the new self, which is being renewed in knowledge in the image of its Creator.”

Again, I’m not trying to say that any of this is easy. But, in Romans 7, Paul talked about his very real struggle to do what he knew was right.

I can testify to how difficult it is for me to keep my heart and life pure, but this must be our ongoing priority.

If we give into temptation and evil, and allow it to take up residence in our hearts, then our entire lives will be harmed and hindered.

I believe that God will give us the relief and the resources we need to develop a pure heart and life.

God says in Rom. 7:24-25, “What a wretched man I am! Who will rescue me from this body of death? Thanks be to God – through Jesus Christ our Lord.”

Sixth Priority - Renew Your Strength Daily. One of my favorite passages is Isaiah 40:28-31, “Do you not know? Have you not heard? The LORD is the everlasting God, the Creator of the ends of the earth. He will not grow tired or weary, and his understanding no one can fathom. He gives strength to the weary and increases the power of the weak. Even youths grow tired and weary, and young men stumble and fall; but those who hope in the LORD will renew their strength. They will soar on wings like eagles; they will run and not grow weary, they will walk and not be faint.”

Just as our bodies require daily nourishment from food and water, so does our spirit. We need daily nourishment for our souls. Where can we get that nourishment?

Psalm 1:1-3 offers us an answer to that question: “Blessed is the man who does not walk in the counsel of the wicked or stand in the way of sinners or sit in the seat of mockers. But his delight is in the law of the LORD, and on his law he meditates day and night. He is like a tree planted by streams of water, which yields its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither. Whatever he does prospers.”

Don’t you want that to be a picture of your life? I want my life to be like a healthy tree extracting nourishment from the soil and the stream nearby,

I want to encourage each of us to make it a priority this New Year to spend some time everyday with the Lord.

For some of us that this has been a priority for many years. There is only one way to do so, by spending time in studying the Scripture and in prayer.

It can also include fellowship with genuine Christians activities. The important thing is that we try to have a consistent time and place to meet with the Lord.

As we meet with the Lord and exercise our spiritual muscles we gain the spiritual strength we need for each day.

Jesus demonstrated the importance of staying connected to the Father as He often made time to be alone with God, and we would do well to follow His example.

Seventh Priority - Act on God’s Promises and Commands. In Philippians 4:9, God says, “Whatever you have learned or received or heard from me, or seen in me – put it into practice. And the God of peace will be with you.”

There is no substitute for faith and obedience. God is pleased when we trust in His promises and act on His commands.

As we move into this new year, let’s make it a priority to live scripturally and claim God’s promises and in so doing walk by faith.

And when we know that there is something God wants us to do or to change, let’s not delay in trying to do it.

In concluding, I wish to remind us that this New Year lies before us unspoiled, unpolluted, naked and structured by God.

May God help us make it the best year for the Church Of Jesus Christ and for each one of us.

I believe the seven priorities we have discussed today can lead us to that end.

i. Let’s forget about yesterday;

ii. Let’s not worry about tomorrow,

iii. Let’s make today count,

iv. Let’s help every person we can,

v. Let’s keep our hearts pure,

vi. Let’s renew our strength daily,

vii. And let’s act on God’s promises and commands.

Let us never forget that God is everything. Without God, life is meaningless. The best of life and eternity are wrapped up in God.

We will never be sorry about focusing our life on serving God.

The next verse after our Scripture reading says, “When Christ, who is your life, appears, then you also will appear with him in glory.” (Col. 3:4).

That’s our hope and our goal! May God bless us as we walk with Him and Serve Him in this New Year!

fields.title: Numbered But Absent
fields.word:
There is a clear reminder that you never know the true condition of the hearts of those around you. The disciples never did figure out that Judas was a traitor until after he had betrayed the Lord Jesus. They always assumed that he was one of them. Perhaps even Judas believed that all was well. Either way, it reminds us that the heart is very deceptive, Jer. 17:9. It also challenges us to be sure that we are in a saving relationship with the Lord Jesus Christ, 2 Pet. 1:10; 2 Cor. 13:5.)

The one crime, which society judges hardly, for which it holds no penalty too severe, is treachery. Of other sins the world is a lenient critic, as it deals very gently with the profligate; it is full of excuses for the self-willed and violent. It has a sympathy with passion, the passion of the sensualist, or the passion of the headstrong, which softens its judgment.

But the traitor receives no mercy at the bar of public opinion. The betrayal of a marriage, family, friend, the betrayal of a cause, the betrayal of one's ministry and country, these are unforgiven and unforgotten crimes.

Even treachery to a treacherous cause is barely tolerated. The law employs it, and disguises it with a specious title. We call it 'turning Queen's evidence,' but still it is repulsive. We avail ourselves of the treachery, but we loathe the traitor. It is an ugly name and an ugly thing, to which no social or political necessity can altogether reconcile us.

Numbered but absent is the an arch-traitor. Judas betrayed a Friend, Who was the very impersonation of Love; he betrayed the cause, in which the eternal interests of mankind are bound up; he betrayed the country, of which we all are citizens, the kingdom of heaven, where we all aspire to dwell.

Acts 1:16-19 KJV “Men and brethren, this scripture must needs have been fulfilled, which the Holy Ghost by the mouth of David spake before concerning Judas, which was guide to them that took Jesus. [17] For he was numbered with us, and had obtained part of this ministry. [18] Now this man purchased a field with the reward of iniquity; and falling headlong, he burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out. [19] And it was known unto all the dwellers at Jerusalem; insomuch as that field is called in their proper tongue, Aceldama, that is to say, The field of blood”.

There is a public and private life of a person, as it lives in two worlds. First, in a very public world that is visible with social responsibilities to live up. Second, is a private world that can be a place of blessing and contentment or it can be a private hell of torture.

These two worlds are tied together, for what is in the heart will be played out in public no matter the packagings. Little things we do shows our character and value.

A person who lives in a private world of goodness, thoughtfulness and holiness will give itself good outward deeds and output. Also, the person whose heart is unclean will absorb itself in something that may take years and then suddenly burst forth in some daring and usually dark deed.

This was the very dilemma of the life of Judas, he carefully cultivated a double life. With that growing gap between his public and private self, Satan took advantage and exploited his weakness.

For a saint and for a preacher, public worship is important but private worship is even very much more important. Always remember that public anointing never rises higher than private anointing, so also is private discipline and value

Worship is a human response to divine revelation. The further away we get from the Cross the greater the liability for failure. By the same token, the closer we get to the Cross the greater the degree of revelation and love for God that takes place.

The story of a Numbered but absent in 1:17 “For he was numbered with us, and had obtained part of this ministry”, sums up the tragedy of Judas. He was numbered with the company but he was never a part of that enterprise.

i. He was numbered but absent.

ii. He was numbered but aloof.

iii. He was numbered but distant.

iv. He was numbered but not committed.

v. He was numbered but not restrained.

vi. He was numbered but never discipled.

vii. He was numbered but never taught.

viii. He was numbered but unconsecrated.

This word numbered sums up one of the life liabilities. Our name can be listed on the roll but when we aren’t really willing to sacrifice, to be taught, take responsibility, and be discipled, we can’t be part of the enterprise, but a spectator and betrayer.

Outwardly, Judas fitted in very well, but inwardly he was in a slow state of rottenness, the corrupt process of decaying and dying.

Judas had been immersed and numbered but absent. How can you know if you are just “numbered but absent”?

a. When you are never prepared for the battle, and encumbered with “stuff”.

b. When you are never counting the cost.

c. When you are content with carnal and all the loose ends of spiritual life.

d. When you are content with all the little besetting sins in the heart.

e. When you are content with infrequent interest in fasting and prayer.

f. When you are not willing to study, for God to approve you.

g. When you not willing to make a sacrificial effort to get immersed in knowledge and worship.

h. When your actions and reactions is oppose to the vision and mission of the ministry.

i. When you are not available and accessible.

j. When you have an indifference to great spiritual truth.

k. When you are willing to settle for a small understanding of the greatness of God.

l. When you cannot follow up programs….

The scripture clearly stipulated that Judas was “numbered,” called and anointed with the 500, 70 and with the 12 apostles with promises and realities of grace.

Luke tells us that Jesus called “the twelve” that included Judas and “gave them power and authority over all demons and to cure diseases, and he sent them out to proclaim the kingdom of God and to heal” in Luke 9:1–2.

Active involvement in ministry is a good and wonderful thing, but it is not, in itself, a guarantee of spiritual life or health.

People fall into a place of danger when they begin to live in the past tense of spiritual life. Far too many are living out their existence in the past tense.

1. Some camp-meeting experience years ago.

2. Some past point in their life when their prayer was more vibrant.

3. Some place in the past when they used to teach Bible studies.

4. Some place in the past where they fought the devil off with a holy vehemence.

5. Some place in the past when they were more involved in the Kingdom of God.

6. Some place in the past when they fought for the mountains of conquest instead of being content in the valleys of apathy.

7. Some place in the past when they fought a much more valiant fight than now.

8. Some place in past tense that held victory.

9. Some place in the past when their dreams for God were really big.

10. Some place in the past when the manna fell for them daily.

11. Some place in the past when the glory days were still experienced.

Judas saw the greatest life ever lived up close and personal. No better model of faith than Jesus or a better environment for forming faith than Judas had in walking with the Savior.

He directly witnessed the miracles, signs, wonders and mighty deeds of Jesus. When 5,000 and 4000, Jesus fed, Judas was there, he took the bread and distributed it along with the other disciples.

When Jesus calmed the storm, walk on top of the water, raised Lazarus from the dead, gave sight to the blind, heal the dumb and deaf, Judas was there. You can’t have better evidence for faith than Judas had.

Judas heard all the teachings of Jesus, in wisdom, knowledge, insight and understanding. He heard the Sermon on the Mount, so he knew there is a narrow road that leads to life and a broad road that leads to destruction.

He heard the warnings Jesus spoke to the Pharisees, so he knew there is a hell to shun and a heaven to gain. He heard the parable of the prodigal son, so he knew God is ready to welcome and forgive those who have wasted themselves in many sins.

With Judas’s own eyes, he saw the clearest evidence, with his own ears, he heard the finest teaching. With his own feet, he followed the greatest example of righteousness, holiness and its liberty. And yet this man still betrayed Jesus.

“The human heart is beyond understanding” in Jer. 17:9, and there is something incomprehensible about a person who abandons the faith they once professed.

It’s hard to understand how a young person raised by godly parents, or ministers in the context of a healthy life and church, taught the truths of Scripture from an early age, and grounded in apologetics can give up on Jesus.

Judas’s story contains an important lesson for parents, leaders, ministers and friends who grieve over someone they love who has abandoned the faith.

They worry:

i. Where did we go wrong?

ii. What more could we have done?

iii. Did we fail in our teaching?

iv. Did we fail in our example?

v. Should we have immersed our son or daughter or friend, ministers, workers in a different environment?

But Judas teaches us that even the best example, the most compelling evidence, and the finest teaching, the ultimate environment for incubating faith, cannot, in and of themselves, change the human heart.

It was not long before Judas was immersed in the instruction that Jesus gave to all of His disciples. It was an amazing time for Judas as he witness -

1. Never before had he heard such wisdom pour out of a man.

2. He had never encountered a man who could speak, preach, or teach like Jesus.

3. The miracles, signs, wonders and mighty deeds were bum-fizzling to him and yet their power was astounding.

4. All the healings of withered limbs, the opening of stony eyes and hard ears, but what was really amazing for Judas was the dead people that were called back from the grave.

5. He watched the wrenching grief turn to astronomical joy when families watched their dead ones come back to them.

As the days passed, Judas found himself being called upon to be the treasurer for the group. Who knows when the difficulties began but obviously something started turning Judas’ heart away from and against Jesus.

i. Seeds of resentment were sown.

ii. The heart started listening to the wrong voices.

iii. Hope turned to disillusionment.

iv. Fellowship was replaced by distance.

v. Conversation disappeared and cold calculation replaced it.

vi. He became a fault founder

Judas’ real problem was that he got disappointed with God. He found himself committed to Jesus but there were a few strings attached to his commitment. Just enough commitment to get him moving but more than a lack of it to keep him distracted. He was never convicted and none converted.

Judas had some expectations of Jesus that He didn’t live up to. If you serve God for any length of time, you are in for the discovery that there will be a large gap between what you expect from the faith and what you actually experience. I have known of more than one who walked away and backslid because of this dilemma, a God who did not live up to their preconceived conditions.

1. I have watched preachers backslide because of the Judas syndrome.

2. I have watched groups give up and quit because of this Judas element.

3. I have listened almost in disbelief at the accusations that poured forth from the hearts of the disappointed.

All of this turned Judas into a thief and betrayer. The bag became his focus. Little by little he started taking what he had previously put into the bag. What is curious about this matter is that he wanted to take someone’s worship away to support his dark deeds.

Love is better than reason. We want no reasoning, but love and conscience. Conscience which directs, and love which inspires. Love is better than reason. If we look at the contrast between the two, recall the scene in Simon's house at Bethany. There Judas reasons, while Mary loves.

Here we see the fault of reasoning without love and the unreasoning devotion and uncalculating abandonment of love in Mary. Of her Jesus said, “Where so ever this Gospel shall be preached in the whole world, there shall also this be told for a memorial of her.” Of Judas, “Woe unto that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed; it had been good for that man if he had not been born.”

Judas fell, love might have saved him, but reason killed him. When Mary broke the alabaster box, his dark heart revolted and he accused, condemned, and ranted and amazingly the disciples were influenced by his reasoning, but the Lord Jesus was not deceived, who spoke sharply to Judas.

Notice the incredible contrasts between Mary’s worship and Judas’ deceit and covetousness.

i. Judas had a money box and Mary had an alabaster box.

ii. Judas had ultimately had thirty pieces of silver and Mary had three hundred denarii.

iii. Judas had four months worth of money and Mary had a year’s worth of salary.

iv. Judas had about #95000 and Mary had #285000.

v. Judas loved the money and Mary loved the Lord.

vi. Judas had a hypocritical concern for the poor and Mary had a noble desire for the Lord.

The decision and Choice Judas made, made Satan assault his soul relentlessly. We read about Satan’s attacks on Judas in Luke 22:3-4 “Then Satan entered into Judas Iscariot”. Because of his perverted and unclean heart about Jesus and life, the devil have to put it into the heart of Judas Iscariot, Simon’s son, to betray him in John 13:2.
